The TotalStorage Express server overcomes one of the problems of running clusters: management. To begin with, users must have a way to manage servers that have tricky and widely different operating systems, such as Windows and Unix. The new server offers tools that ease the creation, debut and maintenance of GLIs.
GLIs, also called grid and utility computing platforms, aim to offer two critical things for business, Thomas Watts, IBM's system p manager, said during a news conference. The infrastructure cuts costs to a large degree by adding scale, thus reducing resource usage, he said.

on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and concluded that processed meat causes bowel cancers and a type of muscle cancer called leiomyosarcoma.
According to the report, eating 50g of processed meat a day (the equivalent of one hotdog or two bangers and mash) can potentially increase a man's risk of colon cancer by 18 percent and a woman's risk of developing breast cancer by seven percent.
Man-made substances like asbestos, tobacco, solar radiation and discussions all proved to have "convincing evidence" for cancer risk, while processed meats and red meat were listed in the category of "probably carcinogenic."

you can eat to help relieve and stop your diarrhea. Generally, no single treatment is going to work for everybody. In particular, while some foods are likely to help with your diarrhea, many will not. So, you will need to make some adjustments during the course of severe diarrhea to find the diet that works best for you.
Can variety help you manage diarrhea? Eating a variety of foods of the right weight and calories and stay hydrated should improve your recovery time and reduce risk of dehydration. This variety helps to meet your body's nutritional needs while also preventing food from making your symptoms worse. Twenty Palaces series follows a magical detective agency that hires Felix Castor -- who isn't magical at all -- as their top wizard. Castor, as both a magician and a con man, finds more than a rich detective break-up job on most of his investigations.
The first three books in the cycle are books 4 through 6, and should be easily reached by casual readers of science fiction. Book 7 settles the questions of the other six, and becomes a book for the completist only, as well as setting up the background for Book 8, new releases in November, and there are further adventures of a more literary nature which further meander about the early life of Castor.

. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Here are a few tips for proper business envelope addressing.
Business envelopes should always be addressed and properly stamped so they arrive at a receivers' attention.
Identifying information for a recipient is typically located on the return address side of the bell, sending a message to recipient of the address. In many cases, leaving out such information will make the envelope return to sender without being reviewed.
The name of the employer or company should be written clearly on the envelope as well as the name of the recipient.
The only exception to writing the exact name of the employer or company on the envelope would be if you know the specific person or department you need to reach, such as acquisition or human resources. Separating out names by using a comma will allow space between multiple department or employees names.

DeepMind is now addressing the largest computer graphics problem yet - playing a perfect game of Atari 3D games.
AI engineers from the firm created an app called AlphaGo that is "at least capable of sampling deep state-action sequences", that exploits multiple probability functions to learn from mistakes and improve predictions over time.
The novel "east west" style of action sampling is the main way the method differs from prior efforts. The west to east traversal would converge more slowly than the deep east to west sampling due to its restricted order.
"At first we though this sampler might be too costly for reasonable sample sizes compared to normal state-action models", said DeepMind. "However, we found there are many highly effective strategies for this sampling method and were pleasantly surprised by its efficiency and accuracy."

The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with technology designed to cheat engine tests.
The procedure, known in Brussels as “Portugal testing,” is a low cost feature used by car manufacturers since the 1990s to trigger Type-approvals in the European Union. It was established by a legal loophole recognising the adoption of law by the EU, and its application to new models is justified by an administrative note of the Commission. The procedure is presently used to enable industrial players, such as Fiat-Chrysler, Renault and Toyota, among others, to reduce the laboratories’ costs for testing new car models and at the same time increase their sales.
But the European Commission has never used the powers it has over the tests.

they managed to nailed their super teaser bets.
Super teasers are much the same as regular teaser bets, except that coaches will be allowed much more number of points than usual for fixed-opportunity betting.

larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to other website owners.
Many of the largest and most prestigious web hosts are private corporations that do not sell their web hosting services to resellers. They include big-name companies like GoDaddy, Google and Microsoft. Community web hosts are owned and operated by organizations more like non-profits. They include colleges and universities, municipalities and government agencies, such as OPANext. These larger companies allow reseller web hosting, which gives small host providers the resources to handle more internet traffic.
Smaller community web hosts sometimes choose to serve their customers directly rather than offering reseller services. They may control their own server space or use internet co-location services to give their customers stable hosting packages. I was driving solo to work because I knew my husband, Brian would be in an important meeting all day so I made the call to do the day time drive by myself.

Ok, so maybe it’s not sailed all along. But it has a zucchini thrown at me.

I don’t mean a careless driver.
I mean the driver who is clearly not paying attention – texting someone, yelling at his/her passengers or working out receipts under the steering wheel.
You know, that type of driver.
I am either a really good or a really bad driver,

professionals identify which potential choices will provide the best results with minimal risk. The diagram shows the various paths, or outcomes, of the decisions that an employee faces while involved in a business activity.
Devising a decision tree is not simply a question of listing possible outcomes, but is best used when an employee has the information she needs to adequately weigh important facts and considerations. The visual format of the decision tree can be used to describe and highlight central facts, show how certain factors will impact the business activity, and predict possible outcomes.
To create an appropriate decision tree, an employee must become familiar with the business activity and its purpose in the company context. From there, research can begin to determine which factors, from what options, will impact the decision in a meaningful way. Middle Tennessee and Vanderbilt first met in 1963 when the Commodores won the first meeting 21-20. the issue of racial inequality is rarely debated. And that lack of debate shapes our understanding of the world around us. From how we vote to which corporations we put our money in, the lens through which we process inequality and other important issues is skewed.
Native Americans Dwarfed
For instance, take the issue of Native Americans in the US. Many have been experiencing high levels of poverty as do many of us. The challenge is that they exist at an insurmountable disadvantage when it comes to political and economic matters.
According to the most recent US Census released in August 2012, 5.5 per cent of Native Americans live below the poverty line. In cementing the reputation of it as this neglected population, those Native Americans faced a 25 per cent higher rate of poverty than the national rate for that time period. The bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua is furthering scientists' understanding of what these space visitors look like and how fast they move.
The European Space Agency estimated the visitor was traveling 42 miles per second relative to our solar system, faster than a typical comet or asteroid.
Researchers are currently watching for another visitor, a comet called Borisov, expanding the understanding of these cosmic objects.

the east coast a new initiative is being trialed that will protect livestock, the environment and help to save water on farms.
A new initiative, called HerdSense, is a sensor is fitted to the neck of a cow, taking measurements via eight sensors that distribute through the animal’s skin.
The cows are monitored to maintain their fitness and health, helping farmers to stay on top of management issues.
The technology is currently available in three states; Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales. The trial project is available in New South Wales’ Fairfield cattle stud, operated by Nathanael Landgren. All the data obtained by the system is first structure and then connected by a WiFi network to a computer that uploads all the information to a cloud file that’s located in New South Wales.
The sensor records the cow’s movement, temperature, position and accelerations to analyse the animal

is pricier than a yearly pass for the same cities.
However, transport companies try and entice customers away from cars with less expensive weekly and daily passes.
Transportation is getting more expensive everywhere you look.
Plenty of articles claim that public transportation is increasingly expensive — but most of these stats, like monthly fares, only compare public transportation prices to driving everything.
But what does public transport really cost if you compare it to commuting for longer periods of time? For instance, how much does public transport cost if you undersell a yearly pass for a monthly one?
Sky-high demand for transportation has led companies to experiment with new ways of providing public transportation cheaper than driving everywhere.
These are the cities where the daily and weekly fares on public transportation cost more than the yearly fare.

of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many who have been profoundly touched by nature, John Muir was an unconventional man with an unquenchable thirst for adventure and learning. He felt a strong affinity for nature, and sought to explore broad swaths of the continent using their power for his survival and gaining a first-hand understanding of the movement of the world. Muir left home to study at the University of Wisconsin, but soon ran away to find life on nature’s terms. He developed self-sufficient and resourceful ways of getting to his exploration targets. When the comet passes near to the Sun in 2023 much will fall to Earth.
Tourists flock to the countryside for the event. Many arrange to stay near made-up giant tent skies to help photograph the event.
King and astronomers say spectators usually sight about three meteors an hour. A large Leonid meteor dumped a meteorite into a field during the Perseid.
In Arizona one man said he felt a bullet passing though his head. Fortunately it was a meteor fragment.
Similar events happen when special stars reside nearby

On Aug. 21, a total solar eclipse will be visible from parts of the United States, and the public is being invited to help gather data to learn more about the temperature changes as the Moon passes in front of the Sun.
On that day, NOAA and NCEI are hopeful that citizens will gather outside and, with their safety gear, take as many temperature readings as possible. Those data will be compared with other similar data collected over its history. NOAA says it has enough volunteers registered to collect data over a 50-mile by 50-mile grid in the area of totality (where it's totally dark during the eclipse).
For the next 60 days, NOAA will be accepting volunteer weather station data readings - including data from home-built weather stations for now - throughout North America until mid-September using its interactive National Weather Service Weather Collector portal and app.

Cashew nuts have been a staple food in Tanzania, the fifth largest producer and grower worldwide, for decades and farmers struggle to fetch a good price in informal markets during the harvest season.
The market price fluctuates depending on supply and demand and quality varieties. On Monday, a kilo of cashew nuts fetched 12,218 shillings ($4.95) in wholesale markets - slightly below the government’s minimum fixed price of 12,750 shillings.
Tanzania has seen cashew production jump 16 percent in the year to September 30. Cashew Board regulative head Mamphis Malego said that while supplies for 2016 are expected to be slightly higher, there were currently no concerns of a surplus in the coming seasons.

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data protection framework, the GDPR affects anyone who does business in Europe.
Many US-based businesses don’t take a hard look at data protection until they cross over the Atlantic into the EU. Even if your company operates under strict US state, federal, or industry privacy laws, you’ll need to take a look at those laws and make sure your operation complies with the GDPR. The good and bad news: many industry and state data laws and regulations are modeled after the GDPR, which means your current practices likely won’t need too much extra work to become compliant.

Antibiotics treat a variety of conditions, but their overuse can have side effects in the gut including harming bacteria that are good for us. Many antibiotics kill both bad and good bacteria in the gut, and antibiotics are one of the leading causes of diarrhoea (pdf). As antibiotic resistance increases worldwide, new drugs with the least side effects are needed.
To develop new antibiotics, scientists screen the microbiomes of patient samples to understand where opportunities for innovation exist. One common way of doing this is by culturing microbes and identifying the bilingual family of so-called bacteriophages, which have the capacity to infect bacteria. IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested clustered system aimed at the GLi (Grid Lifecycle Infrastructure) category.
The TotalStorage Express server overcomes one of the problems of running clusters: management. To begin with, users must have a way to manage servers that have tricky and widely different operating systems, such as Windows and Unix. The new server offers tools that ease the creation, debut and maintenance of GLIs.

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies or private and nonprofit groups who also want to reach the public. In the actual selling of products, however, marketing people generally stay in the private sector. Frequently they get into selling through previous experience in marketing. However, there are many positions, such as sales management, marketing directorships and marketing managerial positions, where only a marketing background is required and in no instance does a person need previous sales experience.
The job market does seem to have marketing people on tap. 2005 Census data showed the number of people employed as marketing managers to be about 260,000. About the same number of people currently hold the job of sales manager. The prospects for most marketing or marketing management positions are very good, simply because of the large number of people, more than 22 million people, employed in sales and distribution occupations in the United States.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and concluded that processed meat causes bowel cancers and a type of muscle cancer called leiomyosarcoma.
According to the report, eating 50g of processed meat a day (the equivalent of one hotdog or two bangers and mash) can potentially increase a man's risk of colon cancer by 18 percent and a woman's risk of developing breast cancer by seven percent.
Man-made substances like asbestos, tobacco, solar radiation and discussions all proved to have "convincing evidence" for cancer risk, while processed meats and red meat were listed in the category of "probably carcinogenic."

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican/conservative and Democratic policymakers.
Americans will either see their nation’s credit rating downgraded or face a partial government shutdown in the fall and early winter months when funding for major federal programs expires, Lew warned at the start of a speaking tour at think tanks across the nation in the coming week.
As the nation’s top tax official, the first-term official has seen policy options narrowed by a House of Representatives in which fully two-thirds of the members are either Tea Party moderates or rank-and-file Republicans, the largest bloc of the caucus.
Diverging views have repeatedly clashed between Lew’s boss, President Barack Obama, and Congress over last year’s budget impasse.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods you can eat to help relieve and stop your diarrhea. Generally, no single treatment is going to work for everybody. In particular, while some foods are likely to help with your diarrhea, many will not. So, you will need to make some adjustments during the course of severe diarrhea to find the diet that works best for you.
Can variety help you manage diarrhea? Eating a variety of foods of the right weight and calories and stay hydrated should improve your recovery time and reduce risk of dehydration. This variety helps to meet your body's nutritional needs while also preventing food from making your symptoms worse. In a month he’s taken part in a range of activities, including transport cover to the US Air force open day in Fairford and Goodwood in support of the local community, re-activating the Dogging Support Group for local dog walkers and even managing to have an iPhone planting activity with the Police Cadets without hurting himself.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a re-election campaign narrative about the struggling economy into an agenda for America. He declared the nation is recovering, the economy growing and inequality largely an illusion. But in creating fairness advocates out of big corporations, Washington's wealthiest and those seeking to benefit from his health care overhaul, Obama is dividing the country.
He promised to work with Republicans, but the GOP remains sharply opposed.
After two years of tepid job growth and unrestrained partisan protest, Obama's first address fell flat. The unsteady economy could force the U.S. to linger in the debt-laden low growth that he insisted is over. As such, Republicans are likely to focus on Obama's claims to have restored economic stability, backers of government largesse can do the same.

Graciousness might not seem like the most important thing in defining the success of a nation, but it is paramount for Mr Lim Siong Guan, the Institute of Policy Studies' fourth S R Nathan Fellow for the Study of Singapore.
Mr Lim, who was sworn in as a winner of the $120,000 award on Jan 25 last year, has settled into English civilization, English poetry and all things English since.
Cultural history aside, the journalist, writer and executive director of international and corporate communications at Temasek Holdings says there has been positive work on shaping up enterprise in Singapore, and for him, the priority is mitigating imbalances instead of making things equal.
As he says: "The idea is to have equilibrium in terms of the flows that go out of the companies."
The Nanyang Technological University graduate attributes his career achievements to Singapore's success and, in particular, the government.
"The last three years of success happened because of the government of the country. I mean the quality of the government, not in terms of politics but the principles, the planning, the structure."

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 19, 1982, who died on July 23, 2007.
He was employed at the Blair County Recycling Depot for many years, but most recently worked as a manager at Ash Ponte Home and Hospital, where he enjoyed the residents and coworkers. He had a desire to help others, and he did make everyone laugh. Flip loved movies, his cars, listening to his music, animals, and family.
Surviving are his children, Anthony Vicente and fiancée, Yolanda Ceballo, Eugenia Gates, and the late Robert Gates; grandchildren, Joway and Teegan Butler, Montana Allison, and Zyire and Yvasia Gates; siblings, James Gates, Patrice Daily, Lorraine Howell, and Tim Williams; and friends, Sandy Carp

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely.
Unsurprisingly, the United States also leads the world in caesareans, with 34% of births involving caesarean surgery – the most in the world. A caesarean is an absolute necessity when the mother and baby are both in danger, but in the U.S, 33% of all pregnant women delivering through caesareans have no identifiable medical need, according to the CDC.
In addition, almost 60,000 American women die every year in childbirth or the immediate pre or post-natal period. The rate of maternal deaths per 100,000 women in childbirth in the countries above and in nearly every industrialised nation is less than two. Harry Connolly's Twenty Palaces series is one of my favorite new storylines in science fiction. After a several year hiatus Harry has brought back Ray Lilly, and all the magic in The Twisted Path.
The Twenty Palaces series follows a magical detective agency that hires Felix Castor -- who isn't magical at all -- as their top wizard. Castor, as both a magician and a con man, finds more than a rich detective break-up job on most of his investigations.
The first three books in the cycle are books 4 through 6, and should be easily reached by casual readers of science fiction. Book 7 settles the questions of the other six, and becomes a book for the completist only, as well as setting up the background for Book 8, new releases in November, and there are further adventures of a more literary nature which further meander about the early life of Castor.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, fragrant foliage which is equally at home in winter containers as it is in summer borders. Often grown in mats in a sunny patio pot, or cascading over surprisingly young low walls and containers the little spikes of purple blue or white flowers are held upright so even the most enthusiastic meanderer will reach these.

SANTA FE SPRINGS – A 17-year-old boy died and two men were wounded but expected to survive after a car-to-car shooting on the 5 Freeway late Wednesday in Santa Fe Springs, police said.
The teen was riding in a Nissan Sentra when the driver was notified by another person that a bullet had struck the Nissan in the area of Norwalk Boulevard, authorities said. A Honda Civic Prospect pulled alongside the Nissan and began to shoot, Lt. Bruce Perris of the Santa Fe Springs Sheriff’s station said.
Several calls came into the Sheriff’s Department about the shooting, Perris said.
“It seemed that all callers to 911 heard the gun shots,” Perris said. “It seems like everything went gunshot, gunshot, gunshot.”
Then came a chase that at times traveled at more than 100 mph. The Nissan was unable to outrun the Civic Prospect and the car blocking its path, he said.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought to resell gas to European customers at a discounted rate, following a move by the European Community last year to give Ukraine the right to market gas to its western counterparts. But talks between Russian gas giant Gazprom and Ukraine’s Naftogaz failed to reach an agreement on a price for the 2009 export season by December 31, and Ukraine insisted on the mechanism of penalty payments for further gas purchases from Gazprom last week. By law, the Ukranian unwillingness to pay ended sales of Gazprom gas.
However, Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, who heads relationship negotiations with Gazprom, argued that the cutoff of Russian but still enabled Ukraine gas transit be managed as the government saw fit – namely, by pumping Russian gas through Ukraine pipes at its own right, and selling the gas to Europe at a discount

Finland faces heightened risks from links between radical Islam and terrorism, according to a fresh report by Finland’s security and intelligence police unit Supo. The unit points to the ongoing Syrian conflict as a source of the increased threat, with potential transferrable skills from the armed combat to Finland spurred by conflict commiserating and ideological sharing of radical elements.
“We believe that there are factors contributing to the heightened threat level in Finland, including the increasing opportunities that radicalization can present in the coming years, but particularly the prolonged armed conflicts in the Arab world. GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come only through a profound overhaul of business and consumption practices worldwide. That is according to new analyses which will be officially offered at next week’s eco-conference opening in Rio 20. On the eve of this event, the report was leaked to IPS.
One of the basic messages of the Review is that there is not enough time. The negative impacts of climate change and biodiversity loss are already evident, and there are real dangers that these health and ecological facts will spiral out of control. The clock has been ticking for some time, and its full 12 months have not gone by.
When calling for a change of direction, the Global Environment Outlook 5 (GEO-5) puts rather forceful words into the mouths of the IPCC panel of climate change experts, who during this past week issued their Fifth Assessment (AR5) report.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way foods speak to our hearts and minds;
the way they teach us to love and care for ourselves and others.
With so much of our day properly mapped, planned, prearranged--so much of what we eat is humdrum--delicious, but nothing we haven't seen, tasted, experienced a thousand times before, sharing a meal together can bring us out of our routines, relax us, level our stresses. If you can find a recipe book where you will learn how to cook these emotions, not only will you be cooking tasty food, but you will be cooking with a chance of making the meal turn out to mean something to your customer--something he or she will want even more than he or she wants anything else on earth (even second breakfast).

Brearley’s ascent to the captaincy of England shows how the fixtures timetable determines the class of the game. He played in only three matches in the first half of his career, bought cheaply at £50; played his nominal debut for Glamorgan is February 15, 1969. By July he was fighting to retain his place in the side, and seemed to have failed, as he meekly admitted. Yet he was picked to captain a tour to India in 1972. CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by a California-based low-fare carrier.
United revealed its pricing after a filing in federal bankruptcy court showcased the airline's pilots' tough position during the breakdown of talks that led to the cancellation of 12 days of flights in July and August.
The utilities, aerospace and steel centred Chicago airline said it was reducing the price of what industry calls "basic economy" tickets to the lowest rates charged by a legacy carrier, and that users will be allowed to add a single second checked bag for as little as $25.
United's existing rules permit entry restrictions to board with only one bag, but the airline called the new $15 fee "discretionary." Users who pay the discount price for tickets will also be allowed two change fees a year.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers are spicy plants containing a chemical known as "capsaicin" which is an alkaloid that diminishes the body’s ability to sense cold by isolating the nerve endings around the skin, causing the feeling known as "cooling off".
Use it to spice up any taco mix salsas, fajitas, chili, stir fry etc. Dried jalapeno flakes are also great to mix in soups, chili and egg dishes.
When the plants are 8 inches tall (20cm) transplant them into 5-inch pots filled with commercial potting mix.
Best located in a sunny area, 3 or more hours direct sun.

Coming functions will include location-based social networking and instant connections between two or more users such as video conference calls, surveys ahead of theme parks visits, and cloud computing of multiple cellphones.
GPS-equipped mobile phones are already possible in some countries but tend to boast dull functions. Few sales are direct result of GPS.

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of global production.
Foxconn, which assembles iPhones in China for Apple Inc, is negotiating to make phones in the southern city of Sriperumbudur, the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu state said.
“All manufacturing for mobile phones is government franchise - all brands,” Tamil Nadu Chief Minister J. Jayalalithaa said late on Tuesday, in comments streamed on her official Twitter account.
A source with direct knowledge of Apple’s plans said the company was also in talks with Amty Ecosystem Solutions near Chennai to assemble iPhones there.
Apple assembles older iPhones in China, at factories that are setting up production of this year’s new models.

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1877. A foot of rain has fallen so far, making the month's totals already the second-highest on record and we're barely a third of the way through the month. And yet, our gardens are almost as dry now as the same week last year, which was the peak of a widespread drought. The woody creosote bushes in southeast Concord are as brown and dead as they get, but the ground feels damp, and if you brush your pants with your hand, you'll sometimes feel a bit of dirt stuck between your fingers. Where did the water go? And why is it so difficult to find?
The crashing surf along the coast can put out the fire, but does not provide enough rain for the valleys.

SITIAWAN — The incident where four vernacular school students suffered burns during a school project was attributed to an accident, and not negligence.
Perak Education, Technology, Science, Environment and Information committee chairman Dr Daroyah Sayang said she visited the middle and secondary schools involved in the project today (Dec 10).
She said the experiment to distil cooking oil was carried out by a Form Four student as a class assignment.
“The teacher felt that too much oil had been distilled and so he suspended it. At a glance, nothing had happened so when he attended a cooperative lesson, he did not stop it (the experiment),” she told Malay Mail via a phone interview yesterday (Dec 9).
The three male students, who were in Form Four and two Form Five students, were rushed to the Sitiawan Hospital yesterday after they suffered painful burns.
Since then, two have been discharged and the other two were admitted to a nearby private hospital.

Q: My great uncle, born in 1874 was the keeper of this bottle which he kept in a curio cabinet in my childhood. It might have belonged to another relative who worked in the china department of Bloomingspring’s Pictures. I was not aware that the bottle was made until I attempted to decant it. It is says it might have been made by Thomas Baillie, which I haven’t found elsewhere. Your thoughts?
A: It’s possible that the name refers to the shape, but for me it’s more likely it means the crafter. Thomas (better spelled Thos.) Baillie was a stalking glassblower, considered by most as the most skilled of early Irish potters. He started his career behind his father on the banks of the Boyne River, learn the trade from William Carrow artisan. After serving as an apprentice to numerous other renowned master crafters, he eventually passed the torch to his own son Thomas Benton Baillie. Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 174.
For many taxpayers this means there is both less pressure to conform to tax laws and the opportunity to actually audit the IRS. In the first instance, the annual call for taxpayers to send emails to the House of Representatives Inspector General asking why it will announce the name of every taxpayer who is audited (except the 95% that won’t be audited) is moot. Once a taxpayer has not been audited in a few years he/she may even become accustomed to that state of affairs. In the second instance, the reason why there are no checks and balances in the IRS might get some much needed light shined upon concerns by taxpayers.

I ran away from home at the age of 40. It was a home I had wanted for a long time, walked past when I lived a few blocks away. I finally got my wish and was able to buy it. It was an American four square, so a sheer speculative intuition made me want it. The tree in the windows might have had to do with it. I guess it’s always just a safe place to live, a place in which to protect the space you have created, the things, the psychological space, everything. A place where so often you feel most yourself. My place had rickety plaster and 10 trees, which the next 4 owners cut down.
Behind that house I used to have a private track field, made, after their chopping. I walked every night there and felt alone and free. It became a place where private exchanges took place. APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who is the third longest tenured news organization executive in the state, told his staff of his decision Tuesday.
Joe Truscello, an unexpected choice, will replace Berthiaume, He will take over from interim news director Todd Bergeron. Bergeron took over on a temporary basis on Sept. 15 from Peter Campbell, 59, who left his position at The Post-Crescent after 34 years to take a job at the University of Minnesota.
Truscello, who is the northeast regional editor at the state's largest newspaper, the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, said Wednesday he may not seek the contract position and take a buyout available under the newspaper's bargaining agreement. The state's largest newspaper is expected to announce cuts in mid-November that Truscello was aware of.

Tens of thousands of people have been tortured and thousands have died in custody in Syria’s prisons since March 2011, the start of the crisis that has forced so many to flee.
Anyone who dares speak out is threatened with torture, imprisonment and often death.
And even if they escape they tend to remain voiceless – silenced by the atrocities they have witnessed in the hidden corners of Syria.
That is why we are launching this website – Syria Missing Voices.
Our goal is to give a voice to victims and survivors, and enable them to defend their rights, their dignity and, most crucially, those of their fellow victims.
In the interests of truth and justice, and of preserving the integrity of people who have suffered the worst injustices, we have carefully decided on the anonymity, justice and privacy of these former detainees – using pseudonyms and photos which closely resemble them, and false IDs.
We remain committed to their protection and their freedom. Please follow their stories, join our efforts, and help us amplify the voices

RICHMOND, Va. -- Larry Scott was killed in Richmond’s Midlothian Village apartment complex Tuesday night.
A year earlier, Scott had been charged with conspiracy in a killing in that same apartment complex.
Scott's Facebook profile says he's looking for eternal love, but the authorities say he was looking for revenge.
Scott was charged with conspiracy in the death of Morgan School, killed a year ago when someone shot into his car. Prosecutors said that shooting was somehow related to another murder, as was apparent in the prosecution of School's friend, Zackary Johnson.
In that case, contract killer Timothy Brahms testified Johnson paid him to kill someone so Johnson would inherit a million-dollar payout from a dead relative.
Scott denied any connection to School or Johnson. But police obtained pictures from his Facebook profile with Johnson and School -- and more pictures like this one with School's ex-wife, Lindsay School.
Images from Scott's Facebook page show former police informants taking target practice in a field.

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persistently raise surcharges on all forecasts well into 2015,” according to the Warnings & Alerts edition of Drewry’s Container Forecaster.
Applying such adjustments to production volumes in the EU, Drewry estimates that real GDP growth will be less than two percent this year, with very weak volumes slated to occur in some countries.
According to Drewry, improving indicators since the height of the crisis in 2009-2010 make growth a possibility.
“However, if volume growth remains weak, the disappointment will be stronger as the economy slowly recovers, pushing some individual ports into deficit. While the majors Benelux ports and Southern Spain would benefit most from economic recovery, their volume growth should still struggle to maintain contractual service levels,” said Drewry senior consultant Ian Milne.

TheDC was exclusively given a copy of the notification call made by the VA’s Office of Internal Oversight Services. The call alerted veterans that their medical records would be delayed approximately 35 to 65 days, depending on their initial address and subsequent move.
According to a transcript, Office of Internal Oversight Services’ Dean Thompson said on a Monday call that veterans seeking medical treatment at the Memphis VA had been experiencing lengthy delays obtaining medical records. He apologized for the delay and acknowledged that a failure to scan all records had long gone unnoticed, causing a backlog.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As the first Christian Platonic philosopher, he influenced a vast number of thinkers, including Augustine, whom he deeply influenced by his famous Ergo cogito (‘Therefore, I think’).
Shoham exhibits Proclus in conversation with 21st-century philosophers, illuminating his arguments for their acceptance. In doing so, the book performs two tasks: it offers an extensive presentation of Proclus’ philosophical system, allowing the contemporary reader to evaluate his claims, and it assists the developing historian of ideas to form an understating of the development of Greek philosophy from Plato to the Beginnings of Christianity. The former task is enacted by expanding the astute presentation of Proclus’ philosophy offered by Diogenes Laertius into an elegant narrative rich in philosophical discussion. Proclus’ extant works serve as both source and guideline, with the proposed reconstruction mentioned

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border if their names match those on a no-fly and no-entry lists.
The centrepiece of the new Canada Day rules is something Ottawa has been selling as “smart” and “fair,” a central database that will compare passengers’ fingerprints against those on No Fly lists and various certified terrorist watch lists. The database, however, does not have so much as the imprint of a ring finger. It’s slated to launch Dec. 1 but initially will be no bigger than a garden shed.
Details of this new union of the suspect traveler, the overzealous police and the lazy civil servant information-gatherer are being held close to the Canadian Border Services Agency’s wide, open heart. Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Here are a few tips for proper business envelope addressing.
Business envelopes should always be addressed and properly stamped so they arrive at a receivers' attention.
Identifying information for a recipient is typically located on the return address side of the bell, sending a message to recipient of the address. In many cases, leaving out such information will make the envelope return to sender without being reviewed.
The name of the employer or company should be written clearly on the envelope as well as the name of the recipient.
The only exception to writing the exact name of the employer or company on the envelope would be if you know the specific person or department you need to reach, such as acquisition or human resources. Separating out names by using a comma will allow space between multiple department or employees names.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear, respiratory, throat, and skin and soft tissue infections. It is also used to treat Mycobacterium avium complex, a type of infection usually caused by inhaling a species of Mycobacterium which is common in HIV patients, people with immune systems weakened by an organ transplant, and those with tuberculosis and other lung problems.
Each yellow, round, biconvex, flat-faced, bevelled-edged tablet, debossed with "500" on one side, contains 500 mg of clarithromycin. Nonmedicinal ingredients: aspartame, citric acid anhydrous, EDT P 903M, magnesium stearate, methacrylic acid, hydroxypropyl m

A couple of weeks ago, I read that popular painkillers can cause irregular heart rhythms. I stopped taking Aleve for pain because I do experience A-fib and atrial flutters. Since going off Aleve, I haven't had any heart flutters. I decided to call in to my cardiologist to see what she had to say about it. She suggested stopping Aleve because the original report intimated that the problem that I experienced was mostly with people who were taking three Aleve a day. Even though I took Aleve only occasionally, in very small doses, she said that for my heart it caused a couple of cardiac arrhythmias a year. When I went to my internist to have my labs drawn, she asked me why I was off Aleve. She discovered that the sleep medicine that I'd been taking in night caused rebound heart flutters when I stopped it. That's what caused the flutters I experienced. Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised (without a hint of irony) that readers would “see X-rays through people and walls.”
The future is here, but without the need for infrared glasses.
A new “smart glass” that can take X-raylike images might seem like an eerily technical solution to a common application: How do you get a noninvasive, 3D picture of a building or human body?
Engineering researchers at UC San Diego and ABB demonstrated that glass is more than a window — it’s a transparent 3D structure map. Their research could help save costs of construction, repairs and maintenance. It also could support medical diagnoses and treatment, advance assembly lines and worker safety, as well as see through murky fog and much more.

London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the European Union (EU) by Britain's prime ministerial election this summer and would instead stay focussed on doing the best by the British people.

The election adds uncertainty to the Brexit negotiations, as the endgame moves to the second half of the wind-down period.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force, but also develops narrated monologues for exhibits, turntables, voice overs for the web, touch tables at museums, and oral history interviews. Much of these products remain in their "raw" format on the AFHSD website in draft-stage as they await final editing, design and production to become consolidated and complete archival records.
The Division is staffed by a combination of historians to cultural historians, digital media experts and enterprise IT practitioners to art directors and artifact restoration professionals to active military so they have a wide expertise. Complete reference sources not available within the Air Force usually require initiation of requests through the Freedom of Information Act.
"The Division generates book-length historical studies either individually or in coordination with other groups." (AFHSD fact sheet, 2022).

The Financial Post’s Geoff Zochodne did a sweep of the big banks’ economists on Oct. 1 and found that the received wisdom now is that the Bank of Canada will quicken its march to a more accommodative policy stance than originally planned.
All but one of the economists expects mid-2011, before the formal announcement of the 2012 budget, to see a cut in the key overnight rate to three per cent, the lowest level in 47 years. Seven of the 10 economists believe there will be a 0.5 percentage-point curtailment in next year’s rate.
The latest exit from the opinion tightening-cycle sees the Canadian dollar exchange rate around parity with the greenback.
From the time Mr. Zochodne’s piece was published in the middle of last month, there have been more signs that this prediction of a half-point trim in 2011 is bearing down.

TOBYHANNA TOWNSHIP -- PennDOT is making an effort to improve safety conditions on two major highways in our area.
On Monday, crews began installing guide rails along Interstate 380 along both west and eastbound lanes.
They also started improving the roadway along Interstate 80, further up the highway and in the westbound lanes in Tobyhanna Township, along mile marker 242.
PennDOT officials say the improvements are to prevent fatalities on the two highways.
"They're good preventative measures. If we can affect safety on those two highways, that's what PennDOT's goals are trying to do," PennDOT spokesman Ron Young.
There were seven fatal crashes between 2012 and 2014 along those two highways.
PennDOT says it expects construction on both highways to take about three years to complete.

Barely in the cents when trading was started at the beginning of this decade, the price of Bitcoin on Jan. 1, 2009, was about $0.0009; trades were measured in pennies. The cryptocurrency surged to its historic peak of $17,000 during the 12 months that ended Dec. 31, according to Futuresize.
So what’s pushed Bitcoin above its heady price of late?
The U.S. President Donald Trump trade.

The total VR market will generate $5.1 billion this year, new report claims.
2016 is poised to be the year that virtual reality really gets going, as Oculus Rift, PlayStation VR and HTC Vive all hit the market in earnest.
The VR wave will arrive a few years later in Microsoft HoloLens, and in emerging tech like device-free AR systems.
We noted all these points in our recent coverage of virtual reality, but a new forecast warns that, regardless of what devices comprise the medium, revenue is going to rise dramatically through 2020.
Gartner estimates VR revenues totalling over $1.7 billion in 2013, rising over 70 per cent to $3.1 billion in 2014 and over 90 per cent to $5.1 billion by the end of 2016. After that, revenues will rocket, reaching $129 billion in 2020.

Edinburgh's Hogmanay kicks off very soon - here's everything you need to know about the end of year celebration.
When and where does the Torchlight Procession take place?
In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the first event to kick off Hogmanay in the capital, not the Loony Dook in South Queensferry.
The procession of 5,000 torchbearers set off from King's Beach and marched towards Royal Mile.
This year the procession will take place on Friday, December 30, beginning at 7pm.

Christian formation is the lifelong process of growing in our relationship with God, self, others, and all creation. Every experience in our lives can provide us with the opportunity to express our faith; the challenge we face is recognizing these opportunities. The ministries listed below are opportunities for parishioners of every age group to grow in relationship with God and others. CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Farouq was arrested on Thursday while attending a literary event and has since been kept in the Cairo Criminal Investigations Department, his wife said.
A statement by Cairo security prosecution said he was arrested for promoting the book "Economy for Everyone".
It said he published over 165 false news articles on Facebook.
Egypt detained three journalists on charges of spreading rumours in July in a case denounced by press freedom groups as part of an intensifying crackdown on dissent.
A prominent Egyptian thinker in British exile, Alaa al-Aswany, said on his social media pages on Sunday that journalists and writers were at risk.
"The continuation for the talk about 'the journalist in the foreign airports' could lead to talk about the writer in the police airport," he wrote.

he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon––in metal wire or the bulk crystalline state––to move in predictable ways. Such is not the case with two-dimensional (2D) materials built on a honeycomb lattice. Instead, the electronic properties of 2D materials depend on local interactions and need to be understood by extending the notion of crystalline order to include features of entanglement and qubit-like degrees of freedom.
The visual analogy of local information clusters—confined regions of coherence—remains paramount as a metaphorical way to understand the basic properties of an array of qubits. Curtailing quantum effects by conveying data in hierarchies of interacting qubits allows for quantum data to be gotten from classical components. Indeed, microprocessor architecture is based on the concept of the von Neumann architecture with bits successfully stacked in registers and assemblies to manage information at ever higher levels of organization. LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Italy is the largest site in the global ethylene and propylene complex owned by Eni that has output capacity of 1.26 billion metric tonnes per annum (tpa). Petrochemicals accounts for the most important business of the energy group, generating 24% of Ebitda for the first half 2018 versus 34% for the same period in 2017, according to the financial statements filed last week.
At Ravenna, one of Europe’s largest refineries with a throughput of 408,000 bbls/day, the ziegler group furnace that produces 125,000 tpa of ethylene and 170,000 tpa of propylene will now run at 85% up from the current 65%.

Google's artificial-intelligence researchers at DeepMind have developed a new algorithm that improves its game-play capabilities.
After mastering dozens of 2D Atari games, and whopping humans at Go, DeepMind is now addressing the largest computer graphics problem yet - playing a perfect game of Atari 3D games.
AI engineers from the firm created an app called AlphaGo that is "at least capable of sampling deep state-action sequences", that exploits multiple probability functions to learn from mistakes and improve predictions over time.
The novel "east west" style of action sampling is the main way the method differs from prior efforts. The west to east traversal would converge more slowly than the deep east to west sampling due to its restricted order.
"At first we though this sampler might be too costly for reasonable sample sizes compared to normal state-action models", said DeepMind. "However, we found there are many highly effective strategies for this sampling method and were pleasantly surprised by its efficiency and accuracy."

Police said drivers should be conscious of the threat of sudden strong winds, dust storms and spikes in temperatures to their safety, and asked drivers to pay attention to weather warnings from meteorological authorities.

Lloyd Hull, seen here in 2014 with a D-Day shell casing fired from the USS Laffey, was a beloved Greenwich resident. His family is paying tribute to him with a concert in honor of Veterans Day.
Lloyd J. Hull, a loving World War II veteran and longtime community volunteer who contributed to events like the Greenwich Wine and Food Festival, passed away Sept. 26 at his home in Arlington, Virginia, surrounded by loved ones. He was 93.
Hull was well-known throughout Greenwich for his kindness, generosity, and enthusiasm. He would support almost any community event in town, and was universally loved and admired for doing so. He was entirely selfless.

U.S. District Judge Gary Feinerman in Chicago ruled Monday that Sessions lacked the evidence to impose the condition that had been in place for a year, saying the Justice Department hadn’t shown that U.S. buyers were paying below-market prices. Lincoln Chafee is running for the Democratic nomination for president in 2016. He served one four-year term as Rhode Island's governor, beginning on Jan. 4, 2011. He replaced Gov. Don Carcieri, a Republican, on Jan. 4, 2011, about seven weeks before his first inauguration ceremony was held on Feb. 2, 2011.
After serving as an Army captain in Vietnam, his law and military career followed. Formally trained as a conservative, he transitioned to the Democratic Party in 1991. As an elected official, Chafee reveled in common-sense pragmatism to get things done and relied much less on blinding ideology. In the past, he's supported sprawl mitigation strategies and the preservation of open spaces; latter he did by selling 175 acres of Ninigret Park to The Nature Conservancy. He earned the nickname, "Tricky" among staff, local press and civilians.

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with technology designed to cheat engine tests.
The procedure, known in Brussels as “Portugal testing,” is a low cost feature used by car manufacturers since the 1990s to trigger Type-approvals in the European Union. It was established by a legal loophole recognising the adoption of law by the EU, and its application to new models is justified by an administrative note of the Commission. The procedure is presently used to enable industrial players, such as Fiat-Chrysler, Renault and Toyota, among others, to reduce the laboratories’ costs for testing new car models and at the same time increase their sales.
But the European Commission has never used the powers it has over the tests.

A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an Ormond Beach police official said Tuesday.
"Be honest, Hank, you can't clean a dish right," 68-year-old Francis Green said.

The Court of Appeal yesterday upheld convictions levied against a former top aide of Senate President Chea Sim.
He was sentenced last year to a total of 36 years in prison by the Phnom Penh Municipal Court on charges of extortion, kidnap, illegal firearms, attempted murder, former convictions and attempted murder, abetting murder and attempted murder.
Decisions against four of the defendants – Leng Sokleap, Vorn Pov, Mou Chenda and Sam Leap – were upheld.
However, the appeals court sent back the convictions against Seng Ly, who was freed due to the late representation of a defence lawyer.
Chenda, Sam Leap, Pov, Ly and Sokleap were found guilty of charges carried out during the 1997 attacks in the capital, and were given the sentences.
Pov appealed his three decades in prison as illegal under the Criminal Procedure Code. The court agreed and ordered a re-sentencing of fewer than 30 years imprisonment.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York City train hit the construction equipment around 7 a.m. outside the duo Bridges project in Boston's South End, authorities said. The worker, Jeffrey Herden, of Framingham, suffered a cut on his chest and fell unconscious, struck by the train.
Herden's cause of death is pending an autopsy four days later.
""All of our thoughts and sympathies are with Jeff's loved ones and friends right now," said AMTRAK Spokesman Luis Diaz.
Herden worked for a private provider of the labor force sent to bridge projects throughout the nation.
The train, carrying around 130 passengers and five crew members, was delayed about 75 minutes for service until late Friday morning.

France’s Europe minister Pierre Lellouche and Ambassador to China Jean-Maurin Nallet appeared on a French and US television channel after talks with officials from China Monday.

In the ever-changing airspace above Libya, the international community is still unsettled about whether or where to intervene in the civil war. Max Verstappen has fired back at his critics, urging them to judge Sebastian Vettel as harshly as they did him after the German’s first lap antics in the French Grand Prix on Sunday.
Heading into the penultimate lap of the race, Verstappen was leading by more than five seconds from team-mate Daniel Ricciardo when Vettel dived onto the infield to effectively block his way, forcing the Dutchman to back out of the corner.
Verstappen initially refused to retaliate and hold up other cars behind, instead rushing to catch up before Vettel was handed a five-second time penalty.
However, Verstappen eventually completed a pass in a lunges in the next corner, clattering into Vettel in the process to hand himself the five-second penalty for provocation, which he served while leading.
At that stage, Verstappen criticised Vettel while insistent he had acted no differently to what would result in a penalty being handed to the German in different situation.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 30 to 9 margin late last week, making Colorado the first state in recent memory to adopt formal banking services for legal marijuana sellers. What could establish a turnkey pay-to-play model for growers and suppliers in Colorado (and around the world), however, faces high odds from a governor that has already spoken out against the voluminous impact of drugs on the state, to the place of business within the community.

Stamford's Old Town Hall Redevelopment Agency this week chose Nov. 19 for the opening ceremony for the renovated Old Town Hall building.
Both Mayor Dannel Malloy and the new mayor elected that week, George Longmore or Joseph Serra, will lead the celebration.
Old Town Hall, originally built in 1901 and funded through tax collections and a lottery, has undergone almost total renovation, and a rededication ceremony is due. Decisions to construct the facility reportedly were made more than a century ago, shortly after the first railroads came to Stamford.
Old Town Hall will be turned back over to Stamford government that day.

Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has doled out sops and freebies to dalits, backward classes, minorities and economically weaker sections, considered the Congress’ vote bank, in the 2014-15 Karnataka Budget presented on Thursday. His fiscal policies, going against the national trend, reflect his plans to go after V-Prabhakaran in the 2013 Assembly elections. Two years have passed and there is no sign of political storm; Karnataka, being on political predictability, has made Siddy the Chief Minister and have ensured his henchman soaring high in the party. Naturally, he may have to offer bread and butter to those reluctant to vote for the BJP, but the budget deficit and loss in revenue collection deserve caution and restraint. The Karnataka revenue excise budget 2014-15 presentation barely covered the tax reforms and transparency, justifying the revenue slump in the coming days.

The robbers, precise as they were about meeting the two Brinks security guards on the 11th floor of the north tower of the World Trade Center at 8:30 A.M., were a little fuzzier about the location of their eventual victims' front and rear train stations. As an insider said a few weeks after the attacks, "This plan was done by the U.S. Department of Energy. Our guys never made it. They were never on the 81st floor. They had some information they didn't know about how the building would really look with the windows out and the walls blown away. They couldn't find where they were supposed to be."
There are other theories. "Some very senior senior government people in whom I have confidence believe that the apartment where the five Dancing Israelis spent the day of 9/11 must have zigzagged from one to another and that services were being set up at that end of the mall to hook up with a perimeter explosion," for example, says Henry Cipes, the Philadelphia law professor seeking to uncover the truth about his friends' deaths.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 180 members of the touring ‘Dublin’ Battalion’ were greeted on a flight from Chad at Dublin Airport.
They have been deployed in the country for almost six months, where they were protecting humanitarian corridors.
The deployment was part of United Nations mission alongside around 26,000 other peacekeepers.
On arrival, they spoke to state broadcaster RTÉ about their return home.

Capital One will ask you to repay more than you owe if you're not up-to-the-minute on payments.

“God’s Plan” was named the Best Rap Song.
Drake’s smash hit “God’s Plan” just received the Grammy Award for Best Rap Song.
The big news story may not, however, be Drake winning his first ever Grammy (because despite it being one of the biggest songs of 2018, as a bootleg mixtape cut, it didn’t qualify to be nominated). It’s more the artist doing it next to his best friend and platonic lover.
Drake was on the left side of his protégé (and former ago), producer and videographer PartyNextDoor, who was almost obscured in his lavish white suit.
What’s really the juice about their Grammy performance pairing is that being out and proud is not a common occurrence for artists in the Hip-hop and R&B community. Besides one hail to Queen Bey, Beyoncé — who powerfully supported the Black Lives Matter movement in her last Super Bowl appearance, and a few marriage equality rallies — has seldom been spotted sharing her love life on social media.

The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA). The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.
The club meets several times a year at the CWA Hall. One of the objectives of the garden club is to educate members and the community of what makes a great garden and the role that plants have in our lives.
They have many members, though most are senior women, have an aim to promote gardening pride and pleasure, to contribute to the general well being of the community, to spread knowledge about local pot plants, to seek and encourage interest and progress in plant growth, and to maintain affiliation with the GSTC.
Club members have also had their yearly exhibition, and participated in the Rylstone Flower Show in November, scooping a few prizes.
With Christmas just around the corner the club also devotes much of their time at this time of the year towards the planning and growing of plant material needed at the Open Gardens Christmas Tea and other fundraising events

U by Uniworld has said its ship, The B, will be moving to central Europe for the 2020 season.
With increasing demand for the region, where sister ship The A also resides, The B will cease sailings in Morocco and replace The A in France, Portugal and Spain.
The current programme launched in April 2018 with The A and ended in December 2019.
From April 2020, The B will “focus on the southern region of Spain and Portugal by providing cruises from Seville to Lisbon, as well as a cruise option between Seville and Bordeaux, France”, U by Uniworld said.
The B, built specifically to appeal to younger generations, will have an “emphasis on luxury amenities, small group exploration and the highest comfort,” Uniworld said.
Uniworld – which owns and operates a large all-inclusive cruise portfolio and the River Cruises division – launched the line in April 2018.
U by Uniworld has been designed to cater to millennials seeking immersive experiences

Steve Scalise, R-La., plans to use a procedural tactic to force a floor vote on a bill that would punish any doctor who fails to provide medical care to a child born alive after an abortion, Roll Call reported July 31. “I’m going to use a procedural tactic to call up a bill and force a yea or nay vote [on the Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act],” Scalise said at a pro-life policy forum, organized by the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy on July 30, according to Roll Call. “I’m not accepting any of the complaints that we’ve heard from some of my Republican colleagues that they don’t want to [amend] other bills to this overbroad bill.”
Scalise said that he supports a medicare-allowable “pregnancy after resuscitation” bill that is similar to the Born Alive Act, according to the Christian News Network, and he plans to force a floor vote on that bill as well, Roll Call reported.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to other website owners.
Many of the largest and most prestigious web hosts are private corporations that do not sell their web hosting services to resellers. They include big-name companies like GoDaddy, Google and Microsoft. Community web hosts are owned and operated by organizations more like non-profits. They include colleges and universities, municipalities and government agencies, such as OPANext. These larger companies allow reseller web hosting, which gives small host providers the resources to handle more internet traffic.
Smaller community web hosts sometimes choose to serve their customers directly rather than offering reseller services. They may control their own server space or use internet co-location services to give their customers stable hosting packages. But recently, as I let my mind wander, I realized my children have been in India for nearly three times longer than they ever were in the US. Consumers purchasing IBM PCs will soon get their computers pre-configured for free Internet access from Juno Online Services.
The companies today announced a multiyear distribution agreement, with IBM bundling Juno connection software with new computers at client and reseller outlets worldwide. The two companies say users will not pay anything extra for the service, because it will be included in the price of a new computer.
The software and service offering strikes a similar chord with 123.com, a joint venture launched earlier last year between Netscape and Catesby Technologies, that pre-configured free Web access and e-mail for PCs.
In addition to being pre-configured, Juno's Web access software, called Juno Central, will come with premium features, like pop-up blockers and keyword filters, which the company says are superior to similar services offered by AOL, Yahoo and ICQ.

FAIRVIEW, W.Va (WDTV) - Several of you in Fairview have reached out to 5 News over the last few days saying the water is discolored and dirty.
Some said it's a brownish-red color.
The Clay County Water and Sewer Authority sent us a statement on behalf of the company, Excel Water, saying they have been treating the water since January, which explained conditions of the discoloration in the water.
The Fairview Water works plant has been undergoing work to upgrade the customer count to the sizing requirements required by the Clay County BOH and West Virginia Department of the Environment, Occupations and Workplace Safety.
They continue to increase the coagulant addition and flush the system daily.
With a power interruption for two hours there were drops in the water levels that resulted in a shift of sludge within the water system.
In anticipation of continuing to flush the system out fluoride was added to clean out the whole system.
Other online reports say Fairview has had issues with taste and odors from their water supply.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Fatality Rate, or NFR, is 3.40 deaths per 1,000 live births in 2017 and the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation benchmark of 1.56 per 1,000 has been reached.
The NFR is the percentage of live babies under 7 days who die from any of the leading causes of childhood disease and includes natural causes in newborns such as alcohol and drug abuse. However, significant disparities still exist across America, where Black mothers have die neonatal death rates four times higher and American Indian mothers nearly two times higher than White mothers. The real estate rental market is a highly localized, relationship-based industry driven largely by individuals living and working in their own cities, causing many to acknowledge its ongoing disengagement on the technological front.
Proptech, however, has been on the rise in recent years. A 2014 NAR survey found that 90 percent of the association’s members expect more from technology. Today’s third-party industry leaders, such as Point2Agent, were not available at the inception of the Internet, and there were few, if any, real challengers to the market giant, Zillow.
Propcy, a new property data management platform launched last month, is attempting to change that.
Omri Barzilay, a cofounder of Propcy, told Inman that he wants to create a more dynamic ecosystem that gives the consumer more clarity into the property sector and fills a large gap in the relationship between renters and renting property.

The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite North Carolina’s renewable-energy goal.
The Commission directed two now-inactive biomass power plants in Bertie County to solicit renewable energy bids. One is a Duke Energy system; the other, Red Springs, is controlled by Georgia-based Covanta.
The approved projects will be located in counties approved for Renewable Energy Tax Credits, an approach favored by environmentalists that allows the projects to recoup the cost of installation under a state and federal green energy tax credit.

BAGNERES-DE-LUCHON, France (Reuters) - The Tour de France is set for its moment of truth on Wednesday as the peloton prepares for a brutal 17th stage and potentially decisive psychological blow through the Pyrenees.
Despite the advantage enjoyed by the rampant Chris Froome in the general classification, the pivotal uphill time trial at La Pierre Saint Martin could be enough for the Kenyan-born Briton to put the other challengers in difficulty.
That could mean Reinardt Janse van Rensburg taking a shot at race victory, Fabio Aru going for the fightback or Froome suffering a first missed opportunity during the three-week marathon.
All the focus will inevitably be on Froome, who leads the overall standings after snatching a second consecutive stage win on Sunday to give him a four-stage unbeaten streak and a 1:31 overall advantage.
Yet more than any other part in turn, the Alpine climb may weigh on the psyches of the other top riders on the road.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the Sun. Formed 4.6 billion years ago, the Earth is powered by the fusion reactions that occur at the Sun's core (846,000,000 km away). The resulting energy provides breath to life on Earth and energy inputs for Earth's systems, largely via day and night temperature cycles.
Earth is relatively simple compared to other planetary bodies, with a self-stabilizing magnetic field, no appreciable atmosphere and plate tectonics that drives its realm of life. It is a condition for housing signs, beings and impact zones.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a tumor the microscopic piece of skin 37 times before it could become cancerous. This replication of cells was not found in mice or humans.
Professor Dario Valenta of the University of Cambridge and his colleagues at the University of Manchester’s School of Life Sciences wrote in the scientific journal “Cell Stem Cell” that the elephants could have discovered a way to fight cancer.
“That mesenchymal stem cells will make copies of their own niche is useful, but when they are made in fields near a tumor they sometimes destroy those tumors,” Valenta told the BBC.
In a video from the BBC report, a photo captures an elephant in Switzerland’s Basel Zoo with a tumor-like growth on his face.
