Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control announcement means the fixture of many breweries – bars that serve patrons mixed drinks alongside their gin and beer – are gone.
State law appears to encourage selling spirits at their breweries. To do so, however, distilleries have to obtain permits from Alaska Anchorage – a process requires getting written permission from the state of Alaska.
Alaska is one of two states that impose a cap on total drinking establishments. The number of drinking equates to 5% of all businesses in the state.
Dan Rood, the owner of a distillery in Eagle River, said the change will leave huge gaps in the bar culture of Southeast Alaska, where many people would be expected to use the microbreweries and distilleries.

"Country Music Hair" author Erin Duvall breaks down the 'dos.
You can't think about country music without thinking about hair. Whenever anyone talks about Dolly Parton, her look is mentioned in the first sentence. You can’t think about the history of country music, or its future, without considering the role of its hair, both high-glossed and dirt-flecked, in making and breaking careers. It’s part of the legend of country, as much as guns and fiddles.
Here are a few changes that have happened over the last 50 years.
Hair and fashion trickled down from pop music into the country market in the early sixties, like things tend to. But since country primarily looks to late-sixties-to-present-day pop as her muses, it’s certainly served only to accelerate and deepen. Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halina Karnow, a food writer in England.
His Vietnam War book, “Vietnam: A History,” published in 1983, was the 10th volume of the New York Times Sunday Book Review series “American Journey.” Based on and supplemented by recent classified files from all three branches of the U.S. government, it told the story of the war in a balanced manner with colorful anecdotes and a focus on the tragic and the senseless.
The book brought Karnow national acclaim, the 1984 Pulitzer Prize and several other honors.

Roadwork continues in Madison Twp.
WEST POINT — Madison Township’s road crew continues its work on potholes and cleanup of trees following recent storms.
In his report last Wednesday to township trustees, Civil Service Director Richard Underwood updated them on roadwork.
First, the crew worked on various pot holes and filling those.
"It was a combination of water getting in them from recent heavy rains that pop them out, and papers and stuff from back alleys being washed into the roads,” he said.
Next was checking roads and making sure culverts remained safe from damage from storm water runoff.
“Some are at their upper limits as far as the way they were configured, and we have to monitor until they come back again,” he said.
Madison Township Road Supervisor Kristy Bledsoe-Patton said they've checked 40 culverts in the recent heavy rain. Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which potential choices will provide the best results with minimal risk. The diagram shows the various paths, or outcomes, of the decisions that an employee faces while involved in a business activity.
Devising a decision tree is not simply a question of listing possible outcomes, but is best used when an employee has the information she needs to adequately weigh important facts and considerations. The visual format of the decision tree can be used to describe and highlight central facts, show how certain factors will impact the business activity, and predict possible outcomes.
To create an appropriate decision tree, an employee must become familiar with the business activity and its purpose in the company context. From there, research can begin to determine which factors, from what options, will impact the decision in a meaningful way. For example, an employee who has studied the company's budget may find that the company's ability to cover the activity's entire costs will determine the outcome of

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, in Myanmar's Kachin state, injuring 40 people on Thursday and blocking a nearby motorway.
Fears grew for the 70 workers supposedly buried under rubble, but rescue teams were called off Saturday after finding no casualties or any miners trapped underground.
Not long before the landslide, the jade mine had opened following a smoke-free, air-pumping ban on unregulated mines in the area.
The accident damaged part of the wind-powered anti-pollution equipment, compromising the planned ban on noxious fumes, in a state mangled by conflict between Myanmar army and Christian ethnic-minority Kachin rebels.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp. It works like this: You outline a part of the photo, identify what it’s a slice of (an apple, for example) and it automatically grafts the “new” section of photo straight into your composition. It looks like magic.
Watch the video above to see the technique in action — it’s a far cry from being able to avert karstic disaster like Aifric O’Neil, fantastically devoted mom that she is, but it’s a really nice tool to have in Photoshop, (and other applications, like Illustrator). Future updates to AI are likely to bring this image-enhancing tech in all kinds of areas. For example am ovalising a face could allow for some tasty Tron-y cyber-warrior PTSD therapy. The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, on the App Store under the category ‘poems’ (see Figure 1). Pat Maloney was a gifted experimental musician in the 1970s, until he suddenly stopped playing entirely.
This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2018. Outside of a handful of close friends and family, he made no mention that he planned to eventually stop living. Normally when someone dies there’s a period of mourning. A grieving, bereaved party perhaps clings to memories and signs—whatever the memorial may be. Of course Pat knew that. He was sick, he was dying. It’s complicated, he knew. But he didn’t mention it. None of his friends or family knew about his sickness and its impending curtain.
In retrospect, his silence was his way of writing up that final score sheet: he’d turn up at the appointed moment, completing an improvised overture and ending like a gig awaits a broken theater. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has been re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly.
Mr Ban, 64, won 188 votes out of a possible 193, with none against. He was the only candidate for the post.
Mr Ban said he hoped to work as a "bridge-builder" so that all nations could "step forward together".
Ban Ki-moon had always planned to stand and there was no real opposition.
Iraq abstained from voting, both out of concern that re-electing Ban Ki-moon would cause delay in the establishment of a UN sponsored tribunal to bring to justice those involved in the bombing of the UN headquarters in Baghdad last year, and because they were unhappy on human rights grounds.
Banned by convention from a third term, Mr Ban could have been forced out of office after a first five-year period at the head of the UN.

A British-born sailor presumed lost at sea was not wearing a safety tether when he was knocked overboard during a yacht race, it has been revealed.
John Fisher, who lived in Adelaide, South Australia and was president of the Payneham Sailing Club and a member of its safety steering committee, is believed to have dislodged his tether after the strong winds proved too much for the Beau Geste. He fell into the water within 30 seconds of losing his balance.
Constructed in 1989, the 12-metre yacht has a top speed of over 20 knots, but was upward of 15 knots on the day its accident happened. The circumstances surrounding the accident are not yet clear however, it is widely reported that it was an unexpected moment and was not something that could be anticipated.

This is the first of two major announcements I am making this week.
Now that the dust has settled from last month’s Many Gods West conference for polytheists, I have divined and listened and decided that YES, Many Gods West 2.0 will go forward in 2014. The dates have already been set.
For those who attended Many Gods West, do you remember what happened before this event? In the process, I did a lot of research on what other polytheist incoming-type events had done in the past.
Now that I have had time to fully assimilate all of that data, I have decided that I must change the direction in this direction. Attendees will NOT hear more from the speakers about what they each know. I firmly believe that Many Gods West has to be a bit of diverse and collaborative hand-holding approach, not a one-man lecture fest – not that many of the speakers I had invited to present at this very SPECIFIC conference.
Event attendees will receive homework assignments forthwith to foster learning how to better call to the gods they worship.

A Canton-based food pantry that feeds hundreds of families across western Wayne County is getting a boost as it heads toward the Thanksgiving holiday.
Open Door Ministry, which feeds about 430 struggling families, has a chest freezer donated to them through a program called ReEnergy Recycles.
ReEnergy Recycles brings donors together, choosing non-profits and accepting donations of industrial furnaces, copiers, tractors, vehicles and myriad small items that ReEnergy then dismantles.
The overall program has donated items worth more than $615,000 to this area since
2009, and is on pace to hit $1 million by 2013.
Open Door Ministry's executive director, Gwen Tansley, said the donation — a half-ton, 124-quart freezer — is tremendous for them.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
The study, published this week in the Journal of Marriage and Family, compared 75 grandmothers (averaging 66 years of age) with 79 granddaughters (averaging 38); each was in a 20-year marriage or long-term relationship.
All of the grandmothers provided care for their grandkids for an average of 31 hours per week, and all of the granddaughters reported spending an average of 29 hours per week doing domestic work around the house or caring for their children.
The grandmother-granddaughter dyads were segregated into groups on the basis of the grandmothers' positive and negative interactions. In each group, the grandmothers and granddaughters - who didn't know each other in advance - answered questions about their perceptions of one another.

She already set the record once. Now she's going to do it again.
Hall of Famer Nancy Lieberman set the record for the oldest woman to play in a WNBA game when she was 39 years old, and now at the age of 44, she would like to make history again.
The legend announced Monday that she will appear in two Special Olympics Unified Sports games and add to a historic streak.
Lieberman, who holds over 170 records in the High School Athletic Association of New York, is also the first female athlete to play for the New York Kings and would be a game captain of two Special Olympics Unified Sports games.
Nancy was first 'Game Captain' for Special Olympics gym night at the Gold Gym! Each city has a designated 'Game Captain' and the Coach of the Game. They cheer on the teams as they play and promote a fun Unified environment.
For Unified Sports, two Special Olympics Athletes and one Unified Partner team up to compete and play against each other, which leads to stronger social skills, more supportive relationships, and more fun between athletes.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the software license agreement.
In contrast, open-source ERP apps have largely been the domain of the small and midsized businesses. That trend is changing, however, as three different ERP packages are now available to the open-source community under an open-source license.
The packages are ProjX, from Open Source Leader, UserWorks and JetPac, each of which has been developed by companies licensing open-source technology to create integrated applications. In each case, the companies that license the technology are akin to resellers, distributors or consulting companies. The fact that these companies can now distribute ERP applications comes courtesy of IBM.

Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, musician Bob Dylan and astronaut John Glenn were among a select group of 13 Americans named by President Obama Thursday as the latest recipients of the nation’s highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Obama awarded two present: one to Glenn, who launched into space at age 77 in 1998 and whose historic flight was seen as a confirmation that manned missions to the moon were possible; it was also awarded in part for his past work promoting math and science education.
Dylan became a staple of soundtracks in film and television, particularly for his the anthem “Blowing in the Wind,” which has appeared in more than 250 movies or TV shows, according to the Library of Congress. The Obama citation said the award stemmed from Dylan’s “irreplaceable contributions to American music and songwriting and his profound impact on popular culture around the world.”

University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt Health aims to create “value-based care,” a model in which healthcare providers assume financial risk for their patient’s health. Officials from the operations say the companies were solidifying their deal this week and hope to start delivering care under their new banner sometime in 2021.
The partnership is operating under the name of CareStory. They say the alliance will ultimately provide health services to entire families across the state.
The name Care Story is all-embracing and focuses on beneficence, said Andrea Melone, Division Vice President of Provider Network Development. “All of my care is through one place,” she added. “I’m a family — [and] as I’ve grown over time, I’m giving access to my entire family.”

This law was amended in 2008 with the Family and Medical Leave Redesign and Extension Act. The California Family Rights Act (CFRA) is the statewide analog to the federal law called California Family Rights Act.

MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered it.
It was the third killing of a journalist in Mexico this year. Attention to the killing of Rubén Pat in the southern state of Chiapas by masked assailants reflected the simmering frustration among Mexico’s news media over the alarming level of violence that has erupted during the battle against President Enrique Peña Nieto’s security measures and dozens of other policies and events.
Pat, 36, was shot outside the newspaper’s office as he arrived at work Monday morning. His bosses said a gunman with a plank of wood hit him over the head before tapping him twice with the plank and firing several shots.
Press freedom groups expressed outrage at the killing and accused officials of turning their backs on journalists fearing reprisals.

A move to Fridays is rarely a good sign for a TV show, which was the case for Raising Hope last fall. So while it's certainly disappointing news that the series has been cancelled by Fox, it's not really surprising. The half-hour sitcom was nominated for a pair of Golden Globes even before airing (and they weren't easy come) but couldn't translate the pedigree of Tracy Jordan into Emmy winning propensity.
The series, from Warner Bros., will finish airing its second and final season next year, which puts a bit of a damper on an incredible under-promotion campaign. Last month, we wrote a post highlighting Fox's marketing as "the best they do not promote" and the series and Kevin Hart certainly fit those qualifications. But Hart is flying high off of last year's victory and hence hasn't the need to really work as hard as usual.
Now that the series has come to an end, we'll have to take just few more minutes to contemplate the best setup cliffhangers we'll probably never know.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to overcome the lag and emotion at play when it comes to exiting their trades. However, these rules won’t necessarily ben you, unless you make a few tweaks to the exit side of your algorithm.
For starters: figuring out when a trade should be exited or stopped can be one of the hardest parts of trading. This issue is even more problematic for newer traders who don’t devote time and energy to this problem prior of entering, but they figure it out by trail and error only later on, and by then they already have bad habits in place. I certainly learned that way: the hard way.
So what happens when you spot an opportunity, and 30, 40, 60 minutes later you realize it’s still on? You ignore obvious stops, throw away price charts and stop asking yourself “How much have I won so far?” in

Pretty soon you'll open the audio windows and hear that your boss on the Eastern Seaboard thought that conference call you were on a a few hours earlier was so good, he passed out from excitement....
Being a quiet grownup is only getting harder. Keep your fingers crossed

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s military and conservative political leader, President Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, quoted an unidentified Iranian official who said uranium enrichment at the Fordo site is taking place. The paper said 60 IR-2m centrifuges had been activated. It said Fordo’s startup is a response to the U.N.’s recent decision authorizing “weapons-grade” uranium enrichment. Activating centrifuges, a potential pathway for acquiring such highly enriched uranium — 20 percent purity or higher, needed for weapons, — could serve this purpose as Iran could reprocess the material to suit bomb-grade specifications.

Even with the rotation showing signs of wear and tear, the team’s primary focus heading toward the Aug. 1 non-waiver trade deadline was the bullpen, specifically closer Edwin Diaz.
Diaz has not worked in the past six games and could use some time off. The Mets want him rested for the final month of the season. Though both have pitched better of late — Diaz the past two days, Raley last month — the Mets need another late-inning set-up man. A closing stint by veteran Aaron Loup could be a possible solution.
As for the rotation, the Mets want to make sure their three starters — Max Scherzer, Jacob deGrom and Chris Bassitt — stayed healthy and rested for the stretch.

The mayor tried to rush through a complicated proposal that caught too many Kansas City leaders by surprise. James enthusiastically presented his broad outline to the Kansas City Council with the hope of getting his proposal on the November ballot. He was met primarily by surprise, and that same week a group of prominent Kansas City business leaders met to launch a committee to oppose the mayor's proposal, dubbed Tax Abatement Reform, or TAR for short. Peter Hernandez was that committee's first member.
Certainly the mayor was right that the tax incentives scene in Kansas City was out of hand. By the mid-2000s development had spread across the entire metro area. Companies like Cerner, Sprint, and Hillcrest are now spread across the area, with H&R Block on the south around Southwest Boulevard and 51st and Wal-Mart on a vast tract north of junctions US 70 and I-29. While the new taxes were a good start, the mayor's overreach would overshadow all else in the backlash and scuttle his political plans.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating efforts to win approval for a merger with UPC Switzerland.
From April 15, Sunrise will enter exclusive negotiations with UPC on a potential deal that would marry the Swiss cable company with Sunrise's terrestrial and mobile networks.
The aim is to create Europe's fourth largest cable operator and the third largest mobile network behind Deutsche Telekom and Telecom Italia.
However a spokesman for UPC Switzerland's top shareholder Atreides on Wednesday said he was opposed to any extension of Sunrise's right to issue the new shares, which would otherwise be locked for another three years after the merger was completed.

Dr. Narges Bani Asadi says cancer is a genetic disease, and she is using technology to fight it.
Asadi is the founder and CEO of Bina, a healthcare startup working to make ‘personalized radiotherapy’ on a global scale. Using artificial intelligence (AI) and augmented intelligence (AI), Bani Asadi and her allies at NVIDIA were able to pioneer personalized, and more importantly less invasive, treatment plans for her patients.
“Determining radiation doses in cancer treatment has historically been very time-consuming,” Asadi says. “Today, we can look at one patient’s history very complex genomics and medical images, and based on those we determine a treatment plan with AI and automate the process. Now we can save time and create a more patient-centric treatment plan.”

I thought we were a Tree City and tried to protect all our trees.
I have heard that a house in Flintridge with two magnificent old oak trees just sold. The oak tree in the front is being retained, but the oaks at the back of this home had to be removed for a new house to be built. This seems so sad and meaningless. I can understand a perfectly good tree would have to go if they were diseased or dying and had termites in them. I think when a healthy [albeit dangerous] tree has to come down, it is so much better if the wood can be used in whatever the home will be to be built [when deciding on the new types of building materials that were used]. What gives? According to data collated by Citigroup Research, net inflows into Asian funds have been relatively low at $2.1 billion (Rs9,828 crore today) since August. In the same period, net inflows into U.S. funds have been a mere $500 million (Rs2,200 crore).
However, despite this dispersion, factors such as the rise of intra-Asia trade and the falling cost of funds have pulled global, as well as Asian, funds towards homegrown funds, says a Bloomberg report.
Fund managers also tend to shy away from making the move because the credit differential that gives them an increased return on their better-rated Asian peers is weak. Additionally, as some emerging markets have seen their current-account deficits surged to about a third of GDP this year, mandating a reduction in risk, fund outflows have been inevitable.

And that lack of debate shapes our understanding of the world around us. For instance, take the issue of Native Americans in the US. Many have been experiencing high levels of poverty as do many of us. The challenge is that they exist at an insurmountable disadvantage when it comes to political and economic matters.
According to the most recent US Census released in August 2012, 5.5 per cent of Native Americans live below the poverty line. In cementing the reputation of it as this neglected population, those Native Americans faced a 25 per cent higher rate of poverty than the national rate for that time period. A bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua continues to perplex astronomers a year after it vanished. Here's why a few scientists still wonder if it was alien.
An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to the sun.Oli Davenport/Kelvinsong/NASA/Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
The bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua is furthering scientists' understanding of what these space visitors look like and how fast they move.
The European Space Agency estimated the visitor was traveling 42 miles per second relative to our solar system, faster than a typical comet or asteroid.
Researchers are currently watching for another visitor, a comet called Borisov, expanding the understanding of these cosmic objects.
Bus-sized interstellar objects passing through our solar system may share abilities with aliens whose behemoth ships headed for Earth were thought to have had (or contained) this week in a video game simulation.

How many gubernatorial elections will Pennsylvania hold this November? A trick question? Yes, sort of – but the question reveals an ongoing war of words over how state political leaders should interpret poll numbers as the race to the November 8 election lines up.
For Pennsylvanians, the parties are predictable. Democrats have latched on to favorable job approval ratings for Governor Tom Corbett, which indicate he could well win re-election in November.
Republicans point to President Barack Obama’s low poll ratings, noting that Democrats got clobbered nationally when his approval ratings were even lower in 2010. With a packed gubernatorial gubernatorial slate and no presidential race on the ballot, Democrats believe they will still win statewide this year – but they expect many of their state House and Senate incumbents could get clobbered as well.

Parents in towns at the centre of the Novichok nerve agent poisonings have been warned not to let their children pick up foreign objects.
The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a counterfeit version of the World War Two nerve agent used in the Salisbury poisonings last year.
Clean-up work is expected to last more than a year, affecting 1,000 properties after warning signs have now moved centre-stage.
In both attacks, the victims put the substance on the soft skin between their thumb and forefinger.
Both have been assessed as coming from warfare programme Four – also known as “Novichok” – meaning nerve agent and referring to such substances being created in the mid-1970s.
Westley Coffinshee, a government clean-up expert, says: “We would advise that certain items aren’t picked up by children – things like residential items, bottle caps, that sort of thing – no foreign objects like that.

Making the most of natural resources of farms is critical in today’s environment, where rainfalls are becoming ever so scarce.
While in Queensland the use of animal recognition technology is being used to conserve water, on the east coast a new initiative is being trialed that will protect livestock, the environment and help to save water on farms.
A new initiative, called HerdSense, is a sensor is fitted to the neck of a cow, taking measurements via eight sensors that distribute through the animal’s skin.
The cows are monitored to maintain their fitness and health, helping farmers to stay on top of management issues.
The technology is currently available in three states; Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales. The trial project is available in New South Wales’ Fairfield cattle stud, operated by Nathanael Landgren. All the data obtained by the system is first structure and then connected by a WiFi network to a computer that uploads all the information to a cloud file that’s located in New South Wales.

Matt Pinnella wrote an open letter to the political conventions of his home state’s four congressional districts, explaining the heartbreak after the Nov. 8 election. Of all states, U.S. representatives from California need to win the most seats, as the state exhibits another kind of bigness.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had departed Seattle around 2 p.m. Pacific Time, and was cleared for a grand takeoff when the first officer noticed a red light flashing, signaling a problem in the cargo hold.
According to the airline, the cargo loader did not note the warning lights. After the plane was airborne, a cargo handler reported him asleep in the rear of the cargo hold.
The airline managed to land the Boeing 737 safely in Seattle, which remained in contact with the plane during the 12-mile flight.
"A local fire department team responded to the aircraft and conducted a search and rescue," the airline said. The fire department found the worker sound asleep below the cargo floor.
Airline officials said the worker was admitted to a local hospital after he reported feeling light-headed.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of scam tactics during tax season each of the last three years.
Fred Reeder, special agent in charge for the IRS criminal investigation division, compares filing for taxes to sending checks to companies. Both transactions could be spied on by computer hacking or email scam attacks.
More than 70,000 scam reports were filed with the Federal Trade Commission in 2018. Those complaints are expected to rise this year as the April 17 income tax filing deadline is approaching and people are looking for ways to increase their deductions and tax refunds.
The Taxpayer Advocate Service of the IRS analyzed cybersecurity risks facing taxpayers last year and found they are similar to those faced by financial institutions. While the IRS has carefully restricted which workers can access personal tax information, there are other benefits that could entice hackers.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could have been invented.
On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong opposition to anything that might potentially reduce economic relations between the two parts of the island. The spectre for local nationalists of a hard border on the island for the first time since partition is hanging heavy in the air.
These, however, are questions for Irish politicians to address. The opinion polls show that public opposition to a "backstop" to ensure Northern Ireland remains in the European single market with a frictionless border but with the rest of the UK leaving it, is around 75%. This result suggests that, in newer smaller states, politicians are governing by the vote. Northern Ireland's vote is treated as a "plaything" and the Irish will not tolerate being "kept out" of the single market. Northern Ireland must move to a free trade area with the EU single market. ROCK CREEK -- From calling in Craig Robinson to host the Hollywood-themed 20th annual gala this Saturday, to implementing a new strategic plan, the Washington County Museum is exploring all avenues in a time of transition.
The new plan comes about at an exciting time for the museum, according to Executive Director Katie Parsons-Dove. It recently acquired 74 acres on Willowbrook Road, more than doubling its size from 53 to 127 acres.
The acquisition also doubles the income-generating potential to the museum through mansion tours, farm tours and community events at the new site. A future plan for a mixed residential space is on the books for 2020.
On Sept. 16, the community will take one step further and include the former Willowbrook Manor as a location on an event-filled tour of Washington County that will include a new avenue for business growth -- trolleys.

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that Didi “trumped” Uber in China on grounds that Didi already claims a near-monopoly of the market in terms of car ownership and second taxi licenses that cause time and cost barriers to new market entrants. Eschatology is my cup of tea – that is, I love how all things are hungry, like we are, for a taste of God’s future. This ties into my interests in pedagogy, women’s health, and love.

The hottest day of 2018 was a bad day for a power failure at The Bridge homeless shelter in downtown Dallas.
A power transformer burst into flames shortly before 4 p.m. in a sixty-year-old power substation along Bank Street. Flames burned unchecked for more than five hours, and damages are estimated at $1 million. Texas-New Mexico Power, on the scene, told reporters there was no immediate danger to the public.
But workers at The Bridge said (as they had no running air conditioning) it was a completely different story inside the shelter’s cinder-block halls. Temperatures were staggering, the workers said.
“From one to four it was like a sauna,” said Michael Walton, a counter operator. “When we finally got power it was like an oven.”
The scene at the College Avenue homeless shelter in Dallas were also rather frightening. “It’s like hell in here,” said Isaac Young. “Hell, I don’t mind that” but he did mind the scorching day.

In the wake of mass digitisation, market consolidation and the launch of ambitious new trading platforms, experts in the out-of-home sector are calling for a boost to standards to ensure a smooth evolution away from the conventional model. Erlend Birkeland looks at the key strands
The move to industry standards is already exerting its influence here too with the launch last year of OMA, mainly run by FCB and C3. Presenting brands in terms of efficiency metrics and sales figures, OMA develops business models with a target audience which so far consist mainly of agencies, advertising networks and media owners. It already engages with a growing community of 6,000 subscribers, illustrating how digitisation is reshaping the digital OOH world.
Meanwhile, the strategic trio of Kantar, PwC and Group M – named Collaborate – has commercialised its Outdoor Output Vulnerability (OOV) and has been working with a handful of chosen digital OOH suppliers to create Best Practice guidelines designed to standardise the fragmented parts of the business.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the extension of both runways by 150 feet and a third runway at JFK's easternmost end to allow the furthest-flung planes from having to turnaround in the air, Governor Andrew Cuomo announced in a statement.
"These are massive and critical upgrades to the infrastructure at JFK International, which is in urgent need of repair and expansion for an increasing demand as a major port of entry to the largest city and economy in the world," said Mr Cuomo, who is seeking re-election November 6. It was not immediately clear if there would be adverse traffic or noise impacts to neighbouring Queens.

It may be cheaper than driving, but commuting by public transport can still be pretty pricey.
Commuting to work via public transportation is usually cheaper than driving everywhere.
But in these major cities, a monthly pass is pricier than a yearly pass for the same cities.
However, transport companies try and entice customers away from cars with less expensive weekly and daily passes.
Transportation is getting more expensive everywhere you look.
Plenty of articles claim that public transportation is increasingly expensive — but most of these stats, like monthly fares, only compare public transportation prices to driving everything.
But what does public transport really cost if you compare it to commuting for longer periods of time? For instance, how much does public transport cost if you undersell a yearly pass for a monthly one?
Sky-high demand for transportation has led companies to experiment with new ways of providing public transportation cheaper than driving everywhere.
These are the cities where the daily and weekly fares on public transportation cost more than the yearly fare.
So Floyd Mayweather could afford to change public transportation companies every week,

A small VoIP company has had to change its name after being threatened with legal action over its use of the word ‘cloud’ in its name by European Wi-Fi network The Cloud.
Facing a High Court case, Cloudnet Telecommunications chose in August to end the ‘stand off’ and agreed to change its name following less than four months in business.
DLL International – the parent company of The Cloud – claims the name Cloud and its variations are “rights reserved” and ‘oddly’ demands they should not be used in domains or business names available while it contests its domain name.
Speaking in November 2012, founder of Cloudnet, Daniel Gilbert, explained why he had chosen the name.
Mr Gilbert said: “I chose the name because we are providing ‘a place to work and study without leaving home’ and Cloud was the most natural name.
The Cloud (formerly known as Edge and then The Cloud by Cellular) was launched in the UK in 2008 in 22 stations, but sold this year to Virgin Group for around £20 million. It is also expanding in other countries including Canada.

The Indianapolis City-County Council approved Monday night about $7.1 million of tax abatements over 10 years to support the major refurbishment to its downtown headquarters.
An additional $20.7 million for jobs and economic development will be allotted to Lilly, to further encourage the company to invest an additional $425 million into its headquarters and city employee base. By Kathie Klarreich Kathie Klarreich, a journalist who lives in Haiti, is cofounder of Caribbean Exchange, a San Francisco-based education and action group.
HAITIAN President General Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier has begun to take the political prisoners from Haitian jails and let them out, but economic prisoners remain trapped. On Bosquet Street in Port-au-Prince, Haiti's postwar capital, men continue to labor on the soil. A day of rest is unheard of. Months of a work week are measured by seasons of the sun and gossip. Horse carts provide the only means of out-of-town transport; they line the streets and rumble, coconuts sold to tourists. Below them in a ditch, a calypso speaker drones, and above another speaker spews out what might be UFO sightings. Dirt roads, badly wrinkled, clearly reflect the path of deprivation and humiliation.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible on the surface of that planet unlikely. Other such blasts, on the other hand, don't seem to be powerful enough to prevent populated Earth-size planets from forming. Yet there may be a third class of supernova, which results in stars similar to the sun exploding in their death throes in a way that is so altered - but not necessarily destructive - that it instills in some scientists a renewed optimism for the likelihood of extraterrestrial life.

RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the rebuilding efforts underway following a phenomena that swept through much of Melanesia.
While the world watched the Olympic action taking place in Rio de Janeiro, heavy rains and wind swept homes and buildings in Vanuatu and caused several deaths including five people being killed on the remote Pacific island of Santo. Homes were destroyed and roads were cut by the erosion produced by the approaching natural disaster.
Barris swung and jumped off the podium into the cheering crowd, eliciting an uproar. "Power to the people," the crowd chanted as the dancing weightlifter ran through the stands.

Tenders to redevelop Union Terrace Gardens will close in the middle of this month, it has been revealed.
Aberdeen City Council has still to appoint a contractor for the multi-million-pound revamp of the quality green space in the city centre.
The garden is tucked under what will become Buchan Tower once the £125m scheme has finished and will be the focus of the park in the heart of the district.
It is not known exactly how much the revamp will cost but bids must be of at least £25milion.
A spokesman said: “The impression we gave earlier in the summer was we would tender by September or early October so we will potentially get a decision in January.”
A bid would not be successful if it was costed at more than £75million as that has not been approved by councillors.
Union Terrace Gardens has been off limits to the public for the past three years except for a public consultation which has delayed the he start of the project.
It is hoped that a decision will be made next year with work beginning in 2016.

Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicos, but it remains a fact as we head into 2010. The bottom line: millions of dollars means millions of votes.
Money does seem to have a growing influence on elections, especially in recent years. Political donations by wealthy individuals and corporations reached nearly $2.5 billion spent on federal races in 2006, 26.2 percent more than 2002.
In this same year, records show $25.9 billion was the estimated amount spent on federal and state races in the United States. And in 2008, OpenSecrets.org reported an estimated $2.6 billion spent on races for the Senate, which was the most ever spent in a midterm election.

LinkedIn has responded to criticism of its "social ads" feature over its use of members' names and photos in advertisements on its website.
Many LinkedIn members have complained that the use of their details in this way has gone awry. Links to advertising seemingly placed to "help" them, ended up directing them to applications that weren't appropriate, increases the risk of phishing attacks and constitutes spam. LinkedIn has also been criticised for representing its own in-house services in this way, while the fee-paying products of unaffiliated companies are ignored.
When the social ads features were introduced (this is via a web-based version of the portal and not via a freely-delivered browser plug-in) in May 2007, they promised recommendation services, powered by "Status Update", which was mainly intended to allow employees to draw attention to books and articles or other information they had read and liked, or wanted to send their organisations metadata for.

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the best possible recovery.”
“Concussion” means that a “child has been hit in the head or a blow to the head or body that makes the head move rapidly back and forth” and leads to brain pathology, Charles Swedenborg, a specialist in neurological pediatric emergency medicine, said Thursday on CNN’s Headline News.
Most athletes who suffer concussions recover quickly, with improved symptoms within a week, according to a study from the National Center for Injury Epidemiology and Prevention in Atlanta. But actions by officials in two Washington state towns this week – including one decision to keep a child on the playing field – demonstrate some still have no idea of the long-term risks.
Concern for concussions has grown in recent years, particularly in football and hockey. In August, the National Collegiate Athletic Association sent its 1,100 member schools guidelines

MARIEMONT – Construction has begun on an addition at Mariemont Village Hall to include a Native American Cultural Center that’s being built with the help of a $400,000 matching-funds state grant. The US has to stand up to China's abusive trade practices like intellectual property theft. And we won't leave farmers to face Chinese bullying alone.
In 2011, a group of Chinese nationals came to my farm in South Dakota. They sampled the wheat I grow, checked the weather, and even met some of my neighbors.
All of this happened without the Chinese giving a single yuan to our U.S. economy.
When the Chinese came next month, I don't want American taxpayers picking up the tab, but I do want America standing up to China, which is skirting U.S. trade laws and abusing trade agreements.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to distributed mountaintop or rural locations to improve resilience during winter weather. They expect to produce a prototype within one year with the help of a recent $50,000 award from the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI).
UCLA professors Hongying Pang, Peng Chen, Vijay Narayanan and Jacob Douglass, as well as postdoctoral scholar Yabing Qi, successfully fabricated the flexible snow energy harvester in a UCLA nanoelectronics lab, a biometric engineering lab, and a mechanical engineering lab, demonstrating it works by grounding the system with snowfall and capturing an electrochemical current against a PV cell.

The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube video to explain his philosophy.
That selflessness was borne out of experimentation. For years, Smith has been experimenting with different ways to get the word out about his work, and the 2009 book itself was an exploration in storytelling: The book was printed with part of it missing, and the reader was challenged to "rejoice innocently" by finding the story by reading it without it. It was a meta story-within-a-story with a meta nod to Ambrose Bierce.
This summer, it became clear to Smith that the e-book publishing industry was gaining steam--sparking the birth of Smith's idea to make the Flinch, an examination of boredom in the Internet age, free for pickup online as well as a $10 discount for a signed paperback. “The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many who have been profoundly touched by nature, John Muir was an unconventional man with an unquenchable thirst for adventure and learning. He felt a strong affinity for nature, and sought to explore broad swaths of the continent using their power for his survival and gaining a first-hand understanding of the movement of the world. Muir left home to study at the University of Wisconsin, but soon ran away to find life on nature’s terms. He developed self-sufficient and resourceful ways of getting to his exploration targets. While studying at the university, Muir also wrote for the journal “University Studies.” In that position and while exploring, he stirred up controversy in riled state treasurer and university president in and around Madison. I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different geometric patterns into the wood with scraps of chalk, sowing a fragment of nature into a pattern of the sky and cloud formations. From a young age my mum always bought cassette cellophane tapes, so I could crinkle it and add different coloured tape together for endless possibilities.
I stayed with the tape and quickly got through all the colours in my mum’s endless supply (well she obviously got bored of eight packets and chucked them out). The tape became a mash up between dots and lines, forms and shapes, and created whole different narratives of pop and colour and texture.

What are the lessons we can draw from the removal of leavened foods, and the bland crackers we eat for a full week?
Sometimes those challenging moments, when we feel that we have been flattened and/or that God has shamed us, actually become instruments in His resurrecting us. They contain His grace for us if we allow ourselves to be bent.
God wanted to redirect Paul’s focus to the basics, returning him to the core truths about faith. They harken directly back to Moses’ time. They are part of what the Jews had already received. They are not new, they are not advanced, and they are not insignificant. They are part of the foundation upon which the whole edifice of faith rises.
I pray God finds it in His grace to lead you or I into those quiet times; to remind us that where God has brought us in our spiritual lives surpasses that time in the wilderness, whether or not we feel that way at the moment.
May God bend us in such a way that we bend to His will and become more like Him.

This Is What It's Like To Be A Syrian Refugee Child In Lebanon.
I asked 12 young aspiring journalists who have fled the war in Syria three different questions about what their life is like now, and what their hopes are for the future.
“We went to our house in Syria, and it was destroyed.”
“Unfortunately my grandmother was killed as she tried to cross the border and escape the war.”
“My brother was in an accident in Lebanon which killed another five people who were in the car.”
Confronting these children with these brutal questions was difficult. They were kind, intelligent, and funny. But their faces would fall, and even convulsions would sometimes occur. They were barely able to talk about the experience, but did so in a surprisingly eloquent way. Telling children this harsh reality, is the harshest reality.

Regulators often struggle to keep up with the rapid pace of new technologies which hurts businesses and consumers.
Whether it’s a cutting-edge gadget, an exciting software platform, or an advanced app, consumers want access to these innovations with their wallets, to gadgets in their pockets, and to experiences in their homes.
However, businesses and consumers also want to know they’re interacting with trusted tools, products, and experiences – and industry regulations are a critical way to instil trust.
When regulations are created using risk-based methods, they can help protect consumers by controlling potentially risky innovations.
On the flip side, unnecessarily heavy regulations – intentionally or not – can channel new services and technologies out of the market through delays, excessive costs, or even total blocking.
For example, voice channels have been thoroughly adopted by mobile carriers and developers because the current regulations in Canada mandate a certain channel format for text-to-speech capability. So even though consumers may desire voice channels, they don’t always get them because it takes significant time

ASTONISHING photographs captured the Perseid meteor shower which lit up night skies around the world last night.
The annual event is caused by the Earth crossing the debris from the tail of the Swift-Tuttle comet.
Temperatures reach 1,500C and one-square-metre surface flashes with a billion photons for 100 meters.
Amateur astronomer David King predicts it produces five or 10 meteors an hour – around 250 an hour.
When the comet passes near to the Sun in 2023 much will fall to Earth.
Tourists flock to the countryside for the event. Many arrange to stay near made-up giant tent skies to help photograph the event.
King and astronomers say spectators usually sight about three meteors an hour. A large Leonid meteor dumped a meteorite into a field during the Perseid.
In Arizona one man said he felt a bullet passing though his head. Fortunately it was a meteor fragment.
Similar events happen when special stars reside nearby

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include a longer, more explanatory comment about the original tweet. But there’s also an option for reports to send a false tweet to people where they tag the original tweet as a fake.
To “retweet with comment” on Twitter, write the comment in the “add your comment” box and click the Retweet button. You should then see the “retweet with comment” feature.
Twitter started a test in June 2013, allowing people to tweet for free and co-ordinate with their followers. See more features in below video.

Remnants of bloody rule echo throughout Indonesian archipelago.
As Indonesia marks the death of its former president, survivors of Soeharto's military backed government - from East Timor to Aceh - remember decades of bloodshed generation after generation.
In the southern city of Bengkulu, across the Strait of Malacca from Sumatra island, stacks of last year's seeds line a tin-roofed pulpita in front of the house of commemorations.
Driven by a fervour of justice,Footnote 2 the area's Moslem farmers blast sacred verses from their loudspeakers and drink tea with kris onClick here (sword) stickers affixed to the shiny packets they peddle as they shop amongst the crowds.
Nearly two dozen military abuses committed under Soeharto's rule - an "authoritarian regime" that lasted for around 30 years - are commemorated in this way, as each day the area's residents reflect the violence of Indonesian rule.

Beantown Bedding cofounders Kirsten Lambert and Joan Ripple.
College students can find time for all sorts of activities, but one chore that always seems to drop off the bottom of their to-do list is laundry.
Washing and drying one's clothes could literally take days – and cofounders Kirsten Lambert and Joan Ripple get this. Their Boston-based startup, Beantown Bedding, is a subscription service that helps shorten that to-do list.

A simple injection has helped a music lover get back to playing the piano again.
David Edmunds had been forced to give up playing and was also starting to have problems with driving after developing a problem that left his hand bent out of shape.
But after visiting Dreszler Hand and Upper Limb Rehabilitation at St George’s Hospital in Tooting, a keychain ring with a small O-ring inside his hand has straightened out his hand and enabled him to play the piano, which he said was “astonishing”.
The injection into the elastic band near his thumb and wrist had been developed to help people with arthritis of the hand.
“It’s astonishing,” said the former BBC sound recorder. “I can't believe that it has come so far and it works so quickly and so well.
“I was a qualified musician, but I was advised by my doctor to stop playing the piano because the pressure on the joints in my wrist meant I would probably never be able to play again.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizens.
On Aug. 21, a total solar eclipse will be visible from parts of the United States, and the public is being invited to help gather data to learn more about the temperature changes as the Moon passes in front of the Sun.
On that day, NOAA and NCEI are hopeful that citizens will gather outside and, with their safety gear, take as many temperature readings as possible. Those data will be compared with other similar data collected over its history. NOAA says it has enough volunteers registered to collect data over a 50-mile by 50-mile grid in the area of totality (where it's totally dark during the eclipse).
For the next 60 days, NOAA will be accepting volunteer weather station data readings - including data from home-built weather stations for now - throughout North America until mid-September using its interactive National Weather Service Weather Collector portal and app.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a government fixed price, traders said.
Cashew nuts have been a staple food in Tanzania, the fifth largest producer and grower worldwide, for decades and farmers struggle to fetch a good price in informal markets during the harvest season.
The market price fluctuates depending on supply and demand and quality varieties. On Monday, a kilo of cashew nuts fetched 12,218 shillings ($4.95) in wholesale markets - slightly below the government’s minimum fixed price of 12,750 shillings.
Tanzania has seen cashew production jump 16 percent in the year to September 30. Cashew Board regulative head Mamphis Malego said that while supplies for 2016 are expected to be slightly higher, there were currently no concerns of a surplus in the coming seasons.

The Marine Corps’ footprint in Afghanistan is changing dramatically as a drawdown in forces continues throughout the summer.
The latest changes include a shift in central Helmand province in which one infantry battalion — 3rd Battalion, 6th Marines — left the volatile tactical operating base Mirbat in the upper Helmand valley in mid-May, handing off security duties to a unit from the 1st Battalion, Royal Thailand Marines.
The Marines have shifted their focus to training Afghan security forces, which come in the form of the Afghan National Police and special operations commandos, such as the commando brigade “Badri Force,” which is partnered with the Marine Special Operations Command.
Throughout Afghanistan, the special operations groups, or SOGs as they’re commonly called, are taking the lead as the US draws down forces. The Afghan operations have gradually been shifting toward training and advising Afghan counterparts for years.
In Helmand’s Farah province, so-called “reserve SOGs” are already in place as few units have rotated out of the province yet.

Serious allegations have been made about the deaths of civilians at the hands of Turkish security forces in the overwhelmingly Kurdish town of Cizre in south-eastern Turkey earlier this year.
Local officials told Human Rights Watch (HRW) that gunfights in the early hours of February 25 killed “around 13” civilians in a makeshift bunkhouse – a mobile home that carried the last name of a dead man from a local extended family who had briefly occupied the premises. That came despite promises by security forces not to enter the building or use live ammunition.
Since then, rights groups – who have been kept out of the city for months – have reported similar summary executions, including even of those who were allegedly just surrendering. But the mass slaughter of unarmed Kurdish civilians within an allegedly protected building could, if proven, be among the worst incidents of extrajudicial killings inside Turkey since the 1990s. Will the GDPR affect your business?
Story From LBMC: GDPR compliance: Will the EU’s new data regulation affect your business?
Prepare for major changes in personal data sharing. The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data protection framework, the GDPR affects anyone who does business in Europe.
Many US-based businesses don’t take a hard look at data protection until they cross over the Atlantic into the EU. Even if your company operates under strict US state, federal, or industry privacy laws, you’ll need to take a look at those laws and make sure your operation complies with the GDPR. The good and bad news: many industry and state data laws and regulations are modeled after the GDPR, which means your current practices likely won’t need too much extra work to become compliant.

As CBS 2’s Marcia Kramer reported, investigators said a postcard that read “those shoes would look smashing on the inside of you” prompted the woman to contact police.
“I said ‘what is this about?'” Thalia Shipley told Kramer of the postcard she received last week. “I said ‘give me a break.’ ”
Shipley said she believes the “baby face” postcard was sent to around 20 women in Dobbs Ferry last week. It made reference to two other women who had contacted Dobbs Ferry Police to report similar letters addressed to them.
“A significant portion of the population in our city has gotten mail similar to myself,” said Shipley. “That sends a chill up your back, especially in today’s environment. It’s sad, it’s scary.”

Gas Tycoon 3 - lite version!
Gas Tycoon 3 is a fast-thinking game for fans of pipe puzzles. Your goal is to connect consumers to a source of energy by turning elements in the path into gas pipes so work flows efficiently in an almost limitless array of possible connections that will even build a complicated system. Despite the game's humorous style, it isn't a cartoon - it looks like a toddler's toy based on advanced technology. But what a cute toy it is. The gas flow in your system is charged by a Handpump (a cute bird) and you can make the prevailing wind blow and rearrange the environment using vents playing a strategic role.
The game uses Youlios advanced 3D graphics, based on Gadgeteer directX engine, with moveable wooden background.
There are various achievements and the challenge rotates, keeping things fresh in the long run.

Linda M. LaVigne passed away at her home in Gaylord on Wednesday, March 21, 2012, at the age of 71.
Linda was born in Plainwell, MI, and moved as a child with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. LaVigne, to Alpena, MI. She attended Wayne State University in Detroit, MI, where she received her BA degree with a major in Psychology and a minor in Education. During the summers, she worked at family owned and operated businesses which included restaurant and retail positions for over 25 years. Her husband, Joseph D. LaVigne, preceded her in death in 2004. She had made Gaylord, MI her home for the past 58 years.
Linda excelled in her roles of housewife, mother and grandmother. A person of tremendous religious conviction, she regularly shared her faith with family and friends. All Master students in Teaching and Curriculum (with the only exception of those working towards their first initial teaching certification, who instead complete a Comprehensive Portfolio) need to complete a Master's Essay as the end result of their studies. Under their choice of topic, students identify three or more research questions they wish to answer related to one of the three focus areas specified for their ISL specialization program. They will then select a literature search question to focus their research. In the essay, students design and employ a plan for research to answer their research questions. Students develop this plan along with which data to collect, how to analyze the data, the claims they will make on the basis of their study, the limitations of their study, why their findings are worthwhile and engage in self-assessment.

Nature broke that pact Oct. 25, when a violent downpour unleashed unprecedented fury on the town of Vernazza and the surrounding hills along Italy’s northwestern coast, provoking dozens of landslides and bringing the town — 320 people — to its knees in seconds. The once-proud seaside village is now in tatters.
That spectre lingers on. The hairline cracks that run through Vernazza's venerable stone buildings — beams, bricks and walls shored up by courses of dry wall that they subsequently dammed in 2011 — keep shuddering with premonitory tremors as more torrents scour the hills. “It’s a slow-motion disaster,” warned Mauro Barni, the head of one of the rescue efforts. “I’m very pessimistic about Vernazza. I think that much of it will not be rebuilt.”

BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal meant to intimidate its enemies: Taiwan and India.
But in 1976, Deng Xiaoping, the economic reformer and pragmatist, was in charge. He took it as axiomatic that nuclear weapons are terrible for the human race and asked Dai Yuanyuan, a ballerina in the People’s Liberation Army, to contact Irish rock stars to get rid of what he called “crocodiles” — weapons that were useless. At the same time, Deng told the young dictator and then China’s paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, he was forming a covert group to handle the delegitimization process to initiate worldwide nuclear disarmament. War’s End advocated a no-first-use pledge of the world’s nuclear arsenals.

Lou Kerner of Wedbush Securities, who covers the social Web space, is fond of referring to Facebook as the second Internet. He calls it this, of course, because so much of what one can do on the open Web can now be done on the site. And he used to refer to the Friend Stream as the second Facebook. But in June 2011 he reconsidered, telling a CNBC interviewer that the Friend Stream was really the third Facebook — because the data collection component on Facebook, the backbone of its business and a key differentiator from more traditional social networks, will be the model and menu that dominates the whole forward-looking Internet.
Kerner is no longer averse to IPO valuation. Blind auctioned on Wednesday without detailed images on the official Banksy online shop, the work was noticed Tuesday when it disappeared from around the corner from a nightclub in Bristol, England.
The artwork, called bin-fire, came with an anonymously donated fire extinguisher along with shovels and a broom to make the effect appear more realistic. It is signed Bacon XXO (in religions-based joke), indicating it was the 20th oil painting the elusive artist created to be nicknamed after Francis Bacon the British painter.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of its raw water supply.
As a result, the utility is returning its normal raw water source, which is the Ohio River.
All customers of the Cairo District will be affected by the change in sourcing, but only experienced discoloration up to this point.
The discoloration is caused by an air pocket in the main or service line caused by the chlorination process.
Illinois American Water continues to encourage all customers to use cold water whenever possible to reduce the discoloration.
For more information or to sign-up for any of the free water quality seminars, please call 1-800-422-2782 or the Cairo office at 618-734-2547.

Antibiotics kill pathogenic bacteria. However, they can also kill beneficial bacteria and upset the human body, especially in the gut. Scientists have developed a way to help protect ‘good’ bacteria by using small molecules already found in plants.
Antibiotics treat a variety of conditions, but their overuse can have side effects in the gut including harming bacteria that are good for us. Many antibiotics kill both bad and good bacteria in the gut, and antibiotics are one of the leading causes of diarrhoea (pdf). As antibiotic resistance increases worldwide, new drugs with the least side effects are needed.
To develop new antibiotics, scientists screen the microbiomes of patient samples to understand where opportunities for innovation exist. One common way of doing this is by culturing microbes and identifying the bilingual family of so-called bacteriophages, which have the capacity to infect bacteria. While retention timeframes will vary according to each organization’s business rules, these NARA policies generally apply to electronic records created and received outside of Court Systems or Treasury Departments.
Compounding the urgency for archiving all the revisions of files stored locally and in the cloud, NARA now publicly shares its expectation that the licensing and certification of software used to create and maintain electronic records will meet or exceed rigorous performance standards. Structurally, the movie box office is pointed back to the future, but with a couple of twists.
As we approached mid-July, according to data compiled by Boxofficemojo.com, the domestic box-office revenue sits at $4.51 billion.
That's down 6.3 percent from the same period last year. What's even more discouraging for the studios, however, is that the slack hasn't been grabbed by the growing brand-new ways of watching movies at home. VOD sales and rentals: up substantially. Furthermore, as many analysts predicted (including yours truly), video games have factored increasingly into the equation: Up a relatively paltry 2 percent but still a decent showing.
For the studios, all of the above spells opportunity. Gone are the days when one or two giant blockbusters lit up the fall and were the ticket sellers. Fredericka Wagner has pleaded not guilty to three charges of aggravated murder in a death penalty case that calls for the firing of 12 guards and the demolition of her German farm, where six children and three adults were killed in April 2016.
Court documents released Friday show Shanin Gandhi, one of Wagner’s attorneys, wrote in the motion that prosecutors told him Wagner didn’t do everything she was supposed to do when police investigated after the killings.
Authorities say the killings weren’t random, but Saxonburg man with Pennsylvania ties has been charged and others will likely be charged, too.
Officials have said claims about a slush fund, claims against former workers who called out sick and claims that hospitals refused to help the victims could be used by Wagner’s defense.

The Knoxville area reeled in $32.2 million in economic impact during the Bassmaster Classic, more than projections for some March Madness host cities.
Knoxville and East Tennessee reeled in $32.2 million in economic impact over four days during the 2019 Bassmaster Classic last week in downtown Knoxville.
Combining impact figures from Knox County and Knoxville Tourism, Knoxville Hosts the Classic and Visit Knoxville, the number is primarily a result of visitors from neighboring states – Tennessee, Virginia and the Carolinas – during the tournament’s prime four days.
“When it comes to sporting events, there is a slight adjustment for economic impact, as it’s really based on the guests who come to visit, but it can't be denied that Knoxville put on one heck of a show," said Lance Graber, vice president of operations and client service for Impact Analytics Advisers, which performs all economic impact studies for Visit Knoxville.

Gwyn Morgan, chairman of SNC-Lavalin Group Inc., makes his opening remarks at the company's annual meeting in Montreal, Thursday May 1, 2008.
SNC-Lavalin Group Inc., one of Canada's largest engineering firms, is cutting about 2,100 jobs and closing divisions in the downturn around the global economy.
The Montreal-based company, which has operations in more than a dozen countries, said today it would implement a series of cost-saving measures as it struggles with the prospect of lower government spending on infrastructure and other projects.
SNC-Lavalin, which has 18,000 employees, said the cuts mean almost a quarter of its work force will be let go in 2009.
Roughly 4,000 jobs will be eliminated from SNC-Lavalin's operations in Canada, while some 350 jobs would be cut from SNC's presence outside the country. Just 250 new workers will be hired, the company said.

The State Department detected unusual activity in its unclassified email system that may have compromised some employees’ personal information, a department spokesman said Friday.
Earlier in the week, the State Department notified Congress and workers that there had been unauthorized access to its email system since last December that could affect as many as 29,000 email accounts, of which about 7,000 were still being investigated. Now, Jason Schank, a department spokesperson, said the affected 29,000 email accounts are from business accounts and may have compromised employee personal information.
Schank said the attack affected less than 1 percent of the personal email addresses and less than 0.02 percent of classified accounts.
Schank said that no sensitive or classified information was affected and he is not aware of any incidents of identity theft.

We study the climate. We chose not to fly to D.C. for a conference on it.
This week, more than 20,000 Earth and planetary scientists from all over the world are converging on Washington for the largest meeting of its kind in 20 years. They will spend four days discussing the latest research on climate trends, extreme weather and the potential for identifying and acting on human-caused global warming.
Al Gore’s new movie, An Inconvenient Truth, will be the talk of the conference and a focus of discussion. The documentary chronicles how, after the Miami hurricane abated the last decade and we became detached from the subject, Americans accepted climate change research the same way that they had disregarded it three decades ago: Years ago, scientists warned of global warming to signal the ice could melt and sea levels could rise. Now that the ice is melting and sea levels are rising, those warnings become a nervous mantra. Global warming is no longer predicted. It is happening.

Facebook is holding a Developer Garage today at its offices in Palo Alto, and a number of new app policies will be formally announced. Some of the changes, though, are so dramatic that Facebook has briefed the bigger app and game developers already.
For starters, the company is changing its app policy to accommodate games by outsiders that target teenagers, and instead open the door to games by companies that want to reach those gamers, too. It seems a no-brainer, but until now Facebook’s policy had forbidden gambling games or those clearly targeted at underage audiences. That drama ended when Facebook made a deal with PopCap Games to offer gambling game Bejeweled under the condition that PopCap assured the company it wasn’t tailoring its games to slim the audience based on gambling wants.
So “substantial reason,” which will replace “suitable for all,” could be another battle wedge for advertisers that want to reach young gamers.
Equally significant is the closure of the Audience Network pilot program, in which publishers plugged their brands or Facebook apps inside apps

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users will have a choice of how to license their photos. The new Creative Commons options go south to "Attribution - Non-Commercial," and "Attribution - No Derivative Works."
500px’s Creative Commons licensing comes as little surprise given that niche photo services like Flickr and freeserve TheSlobe, implemented it in recent months. Both Flickr and TheSlobe partner with Clagsville Graphics as their tech supplier.
While open licensing of photos has yet to take off outside of Wikipedia, the idea behind the Creative Commons mechanism is to ease the process of building online content by providing a clear standard of copyright for the pictures, videos and data that gets stored. The Creative Commons options also means companies that rely on user-supplied content have a standard by which they can determine what they can and cannot do with that material.

Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. our planetary collection grows, and telescopes for studying them improve, some astrobiologists say it is time to narrow the hunt. Christopher McKay at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California has come up with an expanded “checklist” for habitability, which also considers factors like a planet’s light levels, radiation exposure and atmospheric composition (PNAS, DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1304212111).
Some items can be inferred just from knowing a planet’s probable composition and distance from its host star. Others will require photographing the planets and examining their atmospheres. Spacecraft with those capabilities are now being developed.
“That doesn’t mean we are positioned to do it yet, but the discussion has gotten very detailed and very specific,” says Adam Burrows at Princeton University.
